Summary: Public Presentation for "Eat You Up" will involve at least one (1) live, in-person reading and Q&A session taking place at an independent bookstore located in Houston (e.g., Murder by the Book) on or around October 25, 2025 at approximately seven in the evening Central Time. Public Presentation will also involve at minimum one (1) live virtual reading and Q&A session conducted online via Zoom or a similar program in early November 2025, at approximately seven in the evening Central Time. Barring occupancy or program limitations, these readings will be free of charge and accessible to all.

Name: Indian Film Festival of Houston (IFFH)
Summary: The 17th Indian Film Festival of Houston (IFFH) will be held on February 21-22, 2025 from 4 - 9:30 pm each day. The Festival will feature film screenings of shorts, documentaries and feature films, Q&A sessions, live artiste performances and discussions with filmmakers. The event is open to the general public and will be held at the Asia Society Texas Center in the Museum district, one of Houston's seven Cultural districts. Filmmakers and distinguished film industry professionals from around the globe will be in attendance. The Festival will also feature networking opportunities and open discussion about film-making.

Name: Indian Music Society of Houston
Summary: Established in 1992, The Indian Music Society of Houston presents eight to twelve concerts annually featuring the worlds highest caliber Indian classical musicians alongside some of Houstons established talents. The organization focuses on presenting Indian classical music in its traditional format. This "chamber style" music is experienced in intimate settings and small auditoriums and is highly immersive and engaging to connoisseurs and newcomers alike. We also serve as the home of the largest Indian percussion education program, with award-winning students performing in private settings and annual public programs around the city.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Ins Mara Bravo
Summary:
Singer Ines Maria Bravo will present her bolero jazz recording project Besos de Fuego to all kind of public at the Looscan Public Library, located at 2510 Willowick Rd, Houston, TX 77027, on November, 15, 2025, 2.30pm. 
The event will examinate the following aspects:
History and original concept: richness of the music heritage and Latino roots; Songs curatorial process; Vision of empower: the feminine empower of Latino women in music; Musicians and technical team; Outcomes; Perform.
The public presentation of the album Besos de Fuego will offer an overview of all the creative project.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Mauricio Rodriguez Anza
Summary: ORBICULAR is a temporary large-scale installation in an old warehouse in EADO, that explores the relationship between the sphere and the orthogonal in the built environment that will challenge common visual perception. It intends to affect sensation of space as each sphere describes different angles of a same reality. The intention is to measure levels of perception and their emotional effect, so it can be adjusted and applied in formats that impact people's daily lives (building facades, public spaces, interior spaces).The effect could also help eliminate chaotic situations in urban areas. Open to the public September 10 - October 24, 2025.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Kurt Stallmann
Summary: The Buffalo Bayou has existed for thousands of years, creating habitat for plants and wildlife and supporting thriving human cultures. During all of these years, the bayou has been listening. From ancient times to the present,  "Listening Bayou" makes these aural memories heard and brings them into a thirty-minute dialogue unveiling the Bayous evolution through sound. Sounds echoing from the above ground are brought below, contained in the almost sacred ambience of the Buffalo Bayou Park Cistern as a reservoir of sound memories. The Buffalo Bayou Partnership will offer six to eight "Listening Bayou" performances in Fall 2025.

Name: Houston Ratha Jatra (Festival of Chariots)
Summary: Houston Chariot Festival, a daylong free event, is held during summer holidays to attract out of town attendees and tourists to Houston area. 2025 festival is scheduled for Saturday, June 28 and will be held at the newly built Orissa Culture Center at 3101 Fuqua St, Houston TX, a handicap-accessible structure located on a park-like land in the heart of the city in an underserved neighborhood to attracts people from all walks of life. This event celebrates universal brotherhood, love and tolerance by showcasing culture and various art forms from different parts of the world displaying cultural diversity of Houston.

Name: Third Ward Cultural District
Summary: The Third Ward Cultural District's public presentations will include Make Music Day at the Eldorado Ballroom (June 2025), Juneteenth Houston's annual Celebrate Freedom Festival at Emancipation Park (June 2025), and a series of four concerts held at the Eldorado Ballroom throughout 2025 featuring both local and touring musicians honoring the legacy of the newly-renovated venue.

Name: Rivkah French Choreography
Summary:
RFC will engage and expand our community-based programming in 2025 with:
Continuing to present new, original contemporary dance choreography and curated events for the public; Continued partnership with the Peavy Senior Center in Fifth Ward to provide free Movement and Music classes for seniors; New partnerships with Montrose Center and Houston Womens shelters to offer free therapeutic movement classes for the at-risk communities they serve; Hosting Queer Positive Movement workshops throughout Houston and surrounding areas; and expanding our low-cost, centrally located studio space to accommodate an increased number of community events and audience members.

Name: SAID Institute
Summary: SAiD INSTITUTE is committed to empowering and elevating the African diaspora through arts, education, and community engagement,   offering a space for artistic expression, innovation, and partnership. We strive to create transformative environments, nurturing resilience and stability within the communities we support.  Our conviction is that the arts are formidable catalysts for societal transformation. By engaging in art production, and showcasing educational endeavors, our goal is to foster a dynamic, inclusive space where creative expression and cultural dialogue flourish. We aim to reframe what black culture and expression can be, by focusing on inspiring spectrums through diverse artistic mediums.

Name: Brian Gendron
Summary: The Riot Comedy Festival (riotcomedyfestival.com) is an annual 4-day community event returning for its 3rd year April 3rd-6th, 2025. For a whole weekend the comedy industry takes over our city as the festival bring in over fifty performers from all over the world including famous headlining standup comedians, up-and-coming comedians, and showcasing Houston-homegrown talent. The Festival was created by award-winning comedian and entrepreneur Brian Gendron alongside his team of associate producers and dozens of volunteers the festival puts on over thirty comedy shows including standup, podcasts, music, national comedy contest, and street carnival with vendors, artists, and street performers.

Name: Thunderclap Productions
Summary: Thunderclap Productions is a Houston-based nonprofit production company dedicated to producing new and under-recognized plays, musicals, and screenplays. We are committed to making the arts accessible to all patrons and have a special interest in producing works relating to social justice and equity. For our next season, we will mount a production of "The Chosen Ones," a new musical about a group of young LGBTQ+ people in a conversion therapy camp (Aug. 28-Sept. 6, 2025, as indicated below) and a new works festival to feature emerging writers and composers.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Tish Stringer
Summary: In October of 2025 we will gather to watch a new documentary shown on 16mm film at the new Rice Cinema in the freshly constructed Art Building at Rice University. The film, The Greenway Projectionists Reel, explores an art piece made collaboratively by the staff at the former Greenway theater. A panel discussion after the film delves into topics such as analog versus digital media, co-making practices, the decline in art house cinemas nationwide and the profession of 35mm film projection. Afterwards there will be a reception with social time for fellowship and celebration with music and refreshments.

Name: Violet Moon
Summary: Dinner's at 8' is a compelling dance performance set for April 2025 at Barnstorm Dance Fest, taking place at MATCH in Houston. The piece brings together dance artists from various backgrounds, using personal experiences around food and communal dining to explore themes of connection and healing. Set around a simple dinner table, the dancers navigate the unspoken dynamics of shared meals, revealing the tension, vulnerability, and deep need for connection that often go unnoticed. This performance will invite audiences to reflect on their own relationships with food, community, and the often-overlooked complexities of gathering together in a post-pandemic world.

Name: International Voices Houston
Summary: Funding will support production costs for International Voices Houston concert performances May 3, 2025 (7pm), May 4, 2025 (3pm), December 6. 2025 (7pm), and December 7 (3pm and 7pm). These performances represent the conclusion of  our 26th Anniversary season 2024-2025 and represent the first concert of our 27th season, 2025-2026. All performances will take place on the MATCHBOX 4 stage at MATCH (Midtown Arts and Theatre Center Houston) in Houston, TX.

Name: Alley Theatre
Summary: Alley Theatre is one of the largest U.S. professional nonprofit theatres outside of New York City and a leader in regional theatre. Reaching nearly 200,000 individuals each year through its productions, educational programs in local schools, and robust community engagement, the Alley serves Houston through workboth on stage and behind the scenesthat reflects diverse communities. In curating the 78th Season (2024-2025), Alley leadership prioritized community feedback, support for artists, and developing emerging playwrights works. The result is a captivating 12-month season featuring 11 productions and 360 performances and employing on average 250 actors, artists, educators, artisans, and administrators.

Name: Art Factory
Summary: Art Factory is Houstons most unique theatre company. We produce more individual musicals than any other local theater company per year, hire entirely Houston-based artists, design all production elements in-house, and introduce our community to underproduced titles and premieres that locals may not be able to witness elsewhere, all within an intentionally intimate setting that fosters connection between audience and art. Funding awarded by the Houston Arts Alliance will allow us to escalate our programming by reducing the impact overhead and production costs, allowing our financial focus to center on artists compensation, and enhancing the artistic experience for Houstonians.

Name: Art in the Heart
Summary: Rusto Fest is a weekend-long celebration of street art, taking place at Art in the Heart, located at 8321 Jensen Dr., Houston, TX 77093. The event kicks off on Friday, April 4th, 2025, as graffiti artists begin transforming our outdoor space with vibrant murals. The main event on Saturday, April 5th, will feature an indoor exhibit showcasing a unique collection of vintage Rust-Oleum spray paint cans and an interactive spray can art display created by local kids. Join us for a weekend of creativity, community, and cultural expression that you wont want to miss!

Name: The Bay Area Youth Singers
Summary: The 24-25 Concert Season includes a Dec. 14, "From Latin to Latin America" collaborative concert with Segundo Barrio Children's Chorus at the historic Villa de Matel in Houston's Eastside, a March 2 collaboration with the Bay Area Chorus "The Voice" scholarship concert, March 8 "Dessert & a Song" Gala show and fund raiser, May 3 "Tell Me a Story, Sing Me a Song" annual Brenda Varvoutis Scholarship Concert, and several community event performances including Sept. 28 Chinese Association "Lunar Festival," Clear Lake Greek Festival, Dec. 8 Dickens on the Strand in Galveston.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Fatima Hye
Summary: As a Houston filmmaker, I would like to finish Development and begin Pre-Production on my project "Aleph", a mathematical and philosophical biopic about Georg Cantor, the 19th century German mathematician who discovered that there are an infinite hierarchy of infinities. I propose a public Table Reading of the script, which brings together the disciplines of logic, math, philosophy, and film. It would most likely take place in November, perhaps through local academic institutions like the University of Houston or through an arts organization such as the Houston Cinema Arts Festival.

Name: Dominika Dancewicz
Summary: This concert project is called "The Museum of Lost Love". It is planned as a music performance with added verbal presentation. The idea is based on a novel by Gary Barker of the same title. Barker's book draws on his experiences of working in conflict-affected areas, he has been praised for creating stories of "grace and passion" out of some of the worlds most violent places. The music will draw from various Yugoslav backgrounds: Serbian, Croatian, Balkan and the story told on stage will tie the tragedy of relationships lost in wars to love as a redeeming force in life.

Name: Carya String Quartet
Summary: The Carya String Quartets 2024-2025 season, "A Sense of Place," will include 15-20 community chamber music performances across Houston that explore the influence of physical and abstract places on composers from the classical era to today. Operational activities include rehearsals, performances, recordings, a new commission, and innovative educational "Inspirations" programs which explore how artists and composers find inspiration in the world around them. As the only all-women string quartet in Houston, Carya features women composers on all programming. The quartet is dedicated to fostering community through chamber music experiences throughout the Greater Houston Area.

Name: Community Music Center of Houston
Summary: Kindred SOUL: The Legacy of King and Gandhi" is a 60-minute performance blending Black music traditions with Indian classical dance. The Community Music Center of Houston and Silambam Houston Dance Company collaborate to explore shared experiences and artistic diversity through soul, jazz, blues, gospel, and ragtime music interpreted via Bharatanatyam dance. This innovative production also highlights the influence of Gandhi's nonviolent principles on Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s approach to civil rights, celebrating the interconnected cultural legacy of two communities. This program will be Sunday Jan. 19, 2024 at Houston's Gandhi Museum. CMCH and Silambam are designated Houston Cultural Treasures.

Name: Community Music Center of Houston
Summary:
The Community Music Center of Houston will present a series of public performances showcasing our commitment to preserving and promoting Black music traditions. Our key events include:
Martin Luther King Jr. Tribute Concert (January 2025); Discovered Treasures Concert (February 2025, Black History Month); Semi-annual student recital performances (Spring and Fall 2025); Annual Legacy Project with Community Artists' Collective (June 2025); Summer Music Youth Camp (June-July 2025).
These events will take place at various locations in Houston's Third Ward and surrounding areas. Specific dates, times, and locations will be announced closer to the events.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Cressandra Thibodeaux
Summary: Getting Back Our Scalps" is a visual arts project, which explores through photography and a short documentary, how my tribe, the Sault Ste Marie Michigan Tribe of Chippewas worked with the German Karl May Museum to get back our tribal scalps. The project explores repatriation and Germany's interest in Native American Culture. By interviewing over 25 German Museum curators, academic scholars, Sault Tribal Members, German Indian Enthusiasts and photographing and filming at the Winnetou Festival, The Karl May Museum and the German powwow at Pullman City for Indian Week, I aim to explore the fine lines between appreciation vs. appropriation.

Name: Czech Center Museum Houston
Summary: The Czech Center Museum Houston offers a range of public events to promote Czech and Slovak art and culture. Our Spring Festival on April 5th celebrates the season with engaging activities, traditional food, and community connections. The summer internship program provides hands-on experience for students, culminating in a presentation on August 10th, where they showcase their curated exhibits. We also host the Apollo Chamber concert on October 17th and explore Milan Kundera through three book club discussions, with the final discussion on September 19th. Our annual holiday market in December shares festive traditions, that celebrate cultural exchange and community engagement.

Name: Dance of Asian America
Summary: Dance of Asian America (DAA) in a unique cultural organization promoting and preserving the rich cultural heritage of Asia through authentic Asian dance. In doing so, DAA sustains traditions, builds international ties, educates Houstonians in cross-cultural understanding and fosters new generations of professional artists. DAA performances and programs are educational for youths, brought to various Houston communities for maximum outreach, mutually beneficial for dancers and audiences alike and accessible to all. DAA reaches over 35,000 people annually through nearly 40 programs and performances for the great Houston area.

Name: Dream Big Books
Summary: Dream Big Books host public presentations designed to inspire and educate through arts and storytelling. In January 2024, during the College Football Championship weekend in Houston, we launched a financial literacy book with former UCLA player and HBOs Ballers actor, featuring interactive activities for underserved children. We partnered with the TCH Palm Center and HAUL in Houstons 3rd Ward to release Michael Montgomerys book on heart health. Our Upcoming projects include a year-long collaboration with the Holocaust Museum Houston on books about Holocaust survivors and a book and film exploring the history of African American hairstyles, highlighting their cultural significance.

Name: Evelyn Rubenstein JCC
Summary: Serving the community since 1936, the J is a communal leader for arts and culture programming in Southwest Houston. Public presentations in 2025 will span our six core areas of theatre, dance, music, film, literary arts, and culinary arts and will include (all dates 2025): our 21st annual Film Festival (Spring); 53rd annual Book Festival (Fall); a local emerging choreographer dance showcase (February); a comedy event (Date TBD); two plays (February and September); a Big Band Music event (January); author events (January and February); and more. Events will take place at the J and at partner organizations.

Name: FLATS
Summary: FLATS is a woman-founded and artists run photography space in Houstons Montrose neighborhood. Since its inception in 2016 as a nomadic exhibition series hosted in homes (or "flats") across Houston, FLATS has showcased over 85 local artists in 8 different zipcodes. In 2019, while continuing our nomadic exhibitions, we expanded to include the only community darkroom and photo lab in the area, along with a magazine dedicated to regional photography. Our space offers film developing services, support, and equipment access for photographers at all levels. At FLATS, we aim to foster a dynamic platform where lens based artists can connect.

Name: Filipino Young Professionals of Houston
Summary: We will organize Filipino cultural dance workshops featuring instructors deeply experienced in Filipino cultural dance to educate and instruct interested members of the public, at no cost, in the rich variety of Philippine dance traditions and the attire of different regions. In turn, the workshops will impart new choreography and cultural knowledge that our dance troupe will continue to use, teach, and perform throughout Houston going forward. Anyone regardless of experience can learn, rehearse, and even perform with us. The series is planned to include an April intensive at Garza Studios with our troupe's ongoing mentors in Parangal Dance Company.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Daniel Levin
Summary: Towards the end of 2025, we will host several art exhibitions across Houston. Proposed venues include the Cultural Center Our Texas, Caf Brasil, Bar Boheme, and the Aurora Picture Show.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Heather L. Johnson
Summary: The Brio Memory Project is a series of participatory landscape interventions with an art exhibition at Throughline in Houston, from March 28April 26, 2025. The project solicits stories from populations affected by industrial pollution through video; drawings; and temporary, site-specific, performative installations near Superfund sites. Drawings embedded with regenerative seeds are released back into sites in recorded performances of healing and renewal. Scheduled events include an opening reception (March 28, 6-9pm); artist talk (April 5, 12-1pm); community reading (April 19, 4-6pm); closing reception and performance (April 26, 6-9pm).

Name: Houston Zoo
Summary: During TXU Energy presents Zoo Lights, the Houston Zoo transforms to immerse guests in the sights and sounds of a winter wonderland. In addition to spectacular displays totaling over two million LED lights, Zoo Lights features hot cocoa and festive treats, carousel rides, and more. A holiday tradition amongst many families, it provides revenue to support the Zoos wildlife-saving mission. We strive to make this event accessible to our community by offering discounted tickets for military, first responders, and educators. It happens each night from 5:30-9:30 pm, except Christmas Eve, Christmas Day and one Wednesday evening (for donor night).

Name: Houston Swing Dance Society
Summary: We host a public presentation of our organization at our Free Community Night, which will happen on Thursday March 13th 2025 at 7:30 pm at the Houston Marriott Westchase. We partner with local Houston artists Dance Force Production and local DJs and mcs to share the joy of Lindy hop. We talk about what social dancing is, how people can get more involved, we have several performances, and we offer all of this completely free. There's a display in the lobby with photos and information about our organizations history and inside the main ballroom we host the interactive community presentation.

Name: Indo-American Association Houston
Summary: Sukoon: Meditation through Music" is a unique initiative that brings the healing power of music to Houston's diverse communities. By blending traditional and contemporary musical forms, this project offers immersive, guided meditation sessions designed to promote mental well-being and inner peace. Set in accessible cultural venues across the city, Sukoon creates calming, reflective spaces where participants can disconnect from the stresses of daily life and reconnect with themselves. With live performances by skilled musicians and community partners, Sukoon is both a cultural celebration and a pathway to collective healing, fostering wellness through music.

Name: Indo-American Association Houston
Summary: IAA Houston, a dynamic and adaptive Indian Cultural Arts organization, has passionately worked for 31 years to steward, create awareness, and promote the rich performing arts and cultural traditions of India, the world's oldest civilization. By presenting a diverse range of artistic and educational events from the Indian subcontinent, IAA preserves the cultural integrity and heritage of Indo-Americans for future generations. Recognized as one of Houstons Cultural Treasures, IAA contributes to the diversity of our city, enriching the lives of the Indo-American community and the broader public through vibrant, multicultural experiences.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Brandon Kafarela
Summary: This short film will premiere in Spring 2025 at select locations throughout Houston, such as REEVES ART and DESIGN, Jardin, and across the festival circuit and social media platforms. Fashion, film, and art enthusiasts alike can come together to celebrate our shared interests and collectively discuss our commitment to growing both the FILM and FASHION industries in Greater Houston. This short film will be created by a collaborative team of local filmmakers and fashion designers who aim to do what we love in a city that we love.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Karen Navarro
Summary:
Blooming is a visual art exhibition of works by the Houston-based Argentinian artist Karen Navarro, that looks to re-indigenize canons of beauty and European symbols of power through the re-appropriation and remaking of imagery and symbols that have functioned as standard for Western culture and the world.
Using crafts, materials and processes learned from family members this exhibition presents mixed media, installation, and photography work that explore the hybridity of the artist's European and Indigenous identity. The exhibition will take place at P.A.C. (300 Brittmoore Rd, Houston, TX) on June 5th to July 5th, with an opening on 6/5/2025.

Name: Korean-American Society of Houston
Summary: It's the 16th anniversary of the Korean Festival Houston, hosted by the Korean-American Society of Houston (KASH), a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization fostering deeper connections between the Korean-American community and the broader Houston community through cultural promotion. The 2024 Festival marked an exciting milestone as we expanded to a two-day Downtown Houston event. With over 40,000 attendees from diverse backgrounds in previous years, the festival promises vibrant performances, delicious Korean cuisine, and enriching cultural experiences. Dont miss this opportunity to immerse yourself in Korea's rich heritage and dynamic culture right here in Houston!

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Laura Spector
Summary: Personal Stories" is a series of paintings exploring the passage of time, grief, loss, technology, and transformation. Inspired by turn-of-the-19th centuryFrench poster advertisements the imagery hides the artists experiences in plain sight of a type of advertisement. This exhibition was specifically created with The Jung Centers mission in mind of greater self-awareness, creative expression, and psychological insight. Through therapy and self-examination, the artist creates a world thatfinds kernels of understanding of what her life means in the context of the chaotic world weshare. There will be a lecture and music performance during the show.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Margo Stutts Toombs
Summary: An old actress walks into a bar and whines, "Bartender, how do I make lemonade out of this lemon of a body?" The Bartender advises, "Forget about lemonade, make a show." So, the old actress found stellar artists  a dancer/comedian and director/actor. They combined their talents to craft The Organ-ic Variety Show  a comedy presentation full of stories, songs, dances and audience games around the topic of aging organs. This show will play on at 7:30 PM August 23,2025 and 2:00 PM August 24, 2025 at the Houston Metropolitan Dance Center, 4916 Main St #100, Houston, TX 77002.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Mary Box
Summary: African-American composers have written incredible arias for baritones to sing with orchestras. However, these amazing works are rarely performed. Houstonian and celebrated GRAMMY and Emmy Award-winning baritone, Reginald Smith, Jr., has agreed to perform in and help curate a concert featuring all African-American composers with me, Mary Box, conducting, to celebrate Black History Month in 2025. The concert will be held at at Midtown Arts & Theater Center of Houston on Saturday, February 1st, 2025 at 7:00pm.

Name: Multicultural Education and Counseling through the Arts (MECA)
Summary: MECAs Presents events are mostly presented Thursday through Saturday between the hours of 6pm and 10 pm. There are two events that always happen the same day in December as they honor traditions on culturally specific dates which causes them to fall on other weekdays.  Most events take place at the Historic Dow School and the TBH Center, however, if necessary MECA will secure a non MECA facility to best suit the work or artists needs.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Joel Aguilera
Summary: Mind, Body, & Soul is a new evening-length dance work presented by Joel Aguilera on May 1st, 2nd, & 3rd 2025 at the Midtown Arts & Theater Center Houston (MATCH). This three-act dance concert uses breakdancings newest olympic criteria, "Mind, Body, & Soul" as a framework for multi styled choreography following breakdancings debut in the 2024 Paris Olympic Games.

Name: Museum of Fine Arts Houston
Summary: Established in 1900, the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston (MFAH), is among the largest art museums in the United States, with an encyclopedic collection of over 75,000 works dating from antiquity to the present. Each year nearly one million people engage with the MFAH through its exhibitions and programming, including special presentations, lectures, symposia, films, family activities, community outreach, and school partnerships. Education is at the heart of the Museums mission, and the MFAH strives to be a center of learning for the entire community with programming that responds directly to the needs and interests of Houstons diverse populations.

Name: Monarch Chamber Players
Summary: Monarch Chamber Players (MCP) is a Houston-based collective of professional musicians committed to taking classical chamber music out of the concert hall and into accessible community spaces. Our year round concerts are free for audiences and create spaces for neighbors and communities to connect with each other and with the musicians. We collaborate with unique community partners for interactive and educational performances at diverse venues, including front porches, yards, parking lots, parks, churches, and schools. These informal settings allow audiences to become more intimately familiar with classical music.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Nicky Sohn
Summary: Nicky Sohn, award-winning Houston composer, partners with Emissary Quartet for the commissioning, premiere, and recording of her new work for flute quartet. This work draws inspiration from the connection and collaboration of female classical musicians despite the many barriers and impediments historically placed in front of them. Composer and performers alike draw on their unique experiences to create a piece that reflects their individual journeys which ultimately brought them together. The premiere of the new work will take place on April 27, 2025 at Archway Gallery. The piece will subsequently be professionally recorded and published.

Name: Recipe For Success Foundation
Summary: This project will culminate in a public presentation of community-based artworks, two large murals celebrating the traditional foodways of the Sunnyside community. These permanent installations will be placed at the intersection of Scott and Airport Streets, at the entrance to Hope Farms. The murals will be publicly unveiled in a day-long celebration of Earth Day at Hope Farms on May 3, 2025. Community residents and visitors will participate in artistic and culinary activities that celebrate the power of food to build a more resilient community, highlighting food traditions shared over generations and grassroots involvement in the local food system.

Name: Ryn Delpapa
Summary: Art for Climate Resilience" combines creative expression and food justice to empower Houstons Third Ward in addressing climate risks such as flooding, hurricanes, and food insecurity. Led by interdisciplinary and public-health-informed artist Ryn Delpapa, the project will engage residents in co-designed workshops that blend artmaking with practical skills in gardening and disaster preparedness. Participants will create two art artifacts: Climate Art Kits and a Food & Climate Literacy Booklet to build community resilience. The culminating public exhibition will showcase this collaborative work alongside Delpapas interdisciplinary climate justice collection, highlighting the powerful intersection of art, environmental justice, and community adaptation.

Name: Samskriti
Summary:
Samskriti's 2025 season includes traditional, contemporary, cross-cultural and multidisciplinary shows with universal appeal. Performances taking place at MATCH, Miller Outdoor Theatre, or JCC's Kaplan Theatre:
2/8/2025 - PURUSHA: Dancing like men - featuring Puneet Panda (Atlanta), Shashank Iswara (Dallas), Vivek Ramanan (NY).
3/23/2025 - THE FOUR HORSEMEN - Jiva Dance Company, NY, explores the symbolism from the story of the Apocalypse through Indian dance.
11/1/2025 - SONGS OF THE DARK LORD - featuring local dance schools.
4/27/2025 - BUDDHA - play in English with dance and music - Primetime Theatre, India.
6/7/2025 - Incredible India: Arisi (Rice), Grains of Life, presented by Singapore's Apsaras Arts with Indian and Balinese dancers.

Name: Sculpture Month Houston
Summary: Sculpture Month Houston is a free annual exhibition and public program series that showcases contemporary sculpture and installation art from throughout the State of Texas. Sculpture Month Houstons Biennial Festival partners with up to 40 venues from museums to airports to alternative art spaces, highlighting sculpture and installation art across the City of Houston. The 2025 Biennial Festival runs October 11 - December 6, with the main exhibition hub at SITE Gallery at The Silos, an iconic decommissioned rice silo complex just north of downtown in Arts District Houston.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Shih-Hui Chen
Summary: Houston is a key hub in the Central Flyway for bird migration. "An Old Lady And A Bird Sitting on the Cloud Drinking Tea," a string quartet for the Formosa Quartet, will premiere in fall 2025 at the University of Houston. Inspired by bird recordings from Cin-Ty Lee, a professor at Rice University, the piece evokes a harmonious coexistence of humans and birds. It starts with a whimsical bird theme and lush harmonies, depicting an old lady and a bird drinking tea, and ends with peaceful night flights, reminding listeners of the serene connection between humanity and nature.

Name: Silambam Houston
Summary: Silambam Houston, the city's premiere Indian classical arts organization, regularly presents programming designed to reach out to diverse audiences, including traditional Indian classical dance and music performances, cross-cultural collaborative dance-theater productions, and our ArtStream festival that features hosted performances by visiting artists. In 2024, we will present a series of at least six performances in diverse genres of Indian classical music and dance, on April 5, June 14, June 22, June 28, July 5 and July 12, 2024. Additional programs will likely be added shortly.

Name: Nia's Daughters Movement Collective
Summary: Shine Your Light" Artistic Offerings inspired by Motherhood will be a combination of creative wellness offerings such as movement classes, a new performance entitled "Shine Your Light" and tours of art exhibitions with Motherhood themes for community members and tourists alike who will in Houston for Shades of Blue's Maternal Mental Health Summit in July 2025.

Name: Nia's Daughters Movement Collective
Summary: Nias Daughters Movement Collective, founded by Stacey Allen in 2018, is a professional dance company with the mission is to create and support art and wellness initiatives through the lens of Black women and girls. Nias Daughters was organized to perform culturally competent dance works while telling our communities' stories. The organization has grown to be a hub for artistic expression across disciplines and a place where collaboration thrives. For 2024 our focus was to create Family Engaging arts experiences throughout Houston, in which we are excelling. Our 2025 goal is to bridge the artistic works with more community initiatives.

Name: Southwest Alternate Media Project (SWAMP)
Summary: Southwest Alternate Media Project (also known as SWAMP) is a local film arts organization that presents workshops, filmmaker screenings, networking events, filmmaker development and co-presents the annual Houston Media Conference which seeks to combine education, networking and development into one city wide event each year.

Name: Theatre Under The Stars
Summary: Founded in 1968, Theatre Under The Stars (TUTS) is a Houston-based non-profit institution dedicated to enriching life through the experience of quality musical theatre and positively impacting lives beyond the stage through innovative education and community outreach initiatives. The company's artistic vision encompasses our organization's core values of equity, diversity, and inclusion, and supports TUTS's commitment to enrich the lives of Houstonians through the power of musical theatre.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Axzel Sequera
Summary: A Woman's Legacy: Honoring Mara Rodrguez' is a musical project that celebrates the profound influence of Mara Rodrguez in traditional Venezuelan music. Through captivating melodies and evocative storytelling, we weave together her legacy of resilience, creativity, and cultural preservation. Join us on a journey that honors her contributions and explores the rich tapestry of Eastern Venezuelan musical traditions she cherished and enriched.

Name: Zine Fest Houston
Summary: Zine Fest Houston (ZFH) is an organization and festival dedicated to promoting zines, comics, and other indie press projects. The festival is free to attend and offers affordable vendor space for creators who publish, distribute, and promote alternative DIY media. It is the only event in Houston that provides a platform for emerging and established zine makers to exchange work and create meaningful relationships that lead to productive collaboration. The 2025 festival will be in November from 12-6pm at The Orange Show Center for Visionary Art, and will feature local and regional zine vendors, all-ages workshops, lectures, and panel discussions.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: India Godwin-Dorsey
Summary: Fragility of a Creative Mind: Rediscovery of Self is a surrealist art installation meticulously crafted with visual and auditory components to vividly depict my transformative odyssey from a period of despair to rediscovering and embracing my authentic self. This immersive experience will be designed to transport viewers into my journey, allowing them to feel as if they are experiencing the transformation alongside me through innovative use of lighting, music, and artwork. Taking place August 16th, 2025 at Vision Light Studios in Houston, Texas.

Name: ISHIDA Dance Company
Summary: ISHIDA Dance Company presents meaning-filled, thought-provoking works that connect emotionally to Houston audiences, providing performances at The Hobby Center at Zilkha Hall on January 10 -11, 2025, and Asia Society Texas Center on June 12-14, 2025. In tandem with these performances, ISHIDA conducts educational outreach dance workshops that explore themes from our performances on-site at Marshall Middle and Northside High Schools (Title One schools) and provides diverse students with complimentary tickets to attend performances, breaking barriers to participation and allowing them to experience the life-giving impact of contemporary dance.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Jillian Conrad
Summary: Watermark is a visual art project that expresses the complexity and importance of the Buffalo Bayou in Houston through on-site community drawing workshops and public exhibition. Jillian Conrad will document onsite along the Buffalo Bayou to create drawings and sculptures that map the dynamism of the bayous water and the ways it connects the flora, fauna and human communities that thrive along its borders. Watermark builds on Conrads landscape- focused creative practice and shares her practice with Houston community groups  through on site drawing workshops and a public exhibitions between Basket Books, Houston Climate Justice Museum and Buffalo Bayou Partnership.

Name: Dr. Lindsay Gary
Summary: AncesTREE is a book of poetry which explores ancestral connections through trees and their roots, metaphorical and physical, throughout Africa and its Diaspora. This original work of poetry is written by Dr. Lindsay Gary and illustrated by watercolor artist Ashley Lilly. Each poem is dedicated to a particular tree and features an original illustration by Lilly. This book will be launched with a book signing and author talk on Saturday, September 6th, 2025, in celebration of Dr. Lindsay Gary Day. Dr. Lindsay Gary Day was proclaimed by Mayor Sylvester Turner and the City of Houston on September 8th, 2023.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Loc Nguyen
Summary: ROSCOE FORD is a short documentary that follows Roscoe Ford, a Houston realtor and rancher, as he traces his family roots and discovers cruel parallels between his current life and the history of his hometown, Wharton, Texas, where his family was enslaved. In July 2025, our goal is to do a film screening that invites residents of Wharton and the Houston Metropolitan area, and eventually through a festival circuit, to encourage conversation around Black generational wealth and systemic racism in the south.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Marc Furi
Summary: I would like to expand and screen a documentary I recently initiated on the historic student murals in Texas Southern University's Hannah Hall Building. The mural program was started by legendary artist John Biggers in 1950 as a student requirement to graduate from the art program he founded. There are over 100 murals on 3 floors of the admin building, Hannah Hall on TSU's campus. I will show the documentary in fall 2025 at the University Museum at Texas Southern. This will include a panel with the curator of the museum, Dr. Alvia Wardlaw and some of the living artists.

Name: Marc Newsome
Summary: The I Love 3rd Ward Coffee Table Monograph will be a compilation of the aesthetic photography of my  disappearing landscapes of the Third Ward area of Houston. Over the past decade I have been documenting many of the scenes and buildings where the community has congregated. For decades these scenes were characteristic of the area. They included businesses, old signage, and other remnants of a pre gentrified area. Most of these places are no more due to the socioeconomic changes of gentrification.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Maria Chevez
Summary: The "Art in the Park" exhibit will be held at the Freed Park Community Center, located at 6818 Shadyvilla Lane, Spring Branch. I will be displaying family-friendly art, prints, and printmaking plates in their exhibit gallery. Additionally, I will be giving two artist talks and will be there on weekends to interact with the community. This is a park I frequently visit to walk and immerse myself in nature.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Mitchell Collins
Summary: The Crab-Eater Survives the Storm" is a collaborative performance art film that will premiere at an event at the Houston Climate Justice Museum in Spring 2025. The film, which will feature a performance by Houston-based artist and curator Salome Kokoladze, will be preceded by readings by local poets and environmental justice activists. The film is being developed by me and my collaborator, trans Filipinx photographer/cinematographer Marion Aguas, and it will also feature an original soundtrack by a local Houston noise artist.

Name: Chukwunonso Ofili
Summary: The Houston Caricature Expo will be held at True Love Studios on April 20th from 4 PM to 7 PM. This event invites the community to come together for an afternoon of art, fun, and refreshments, where talented caricature artists will draw attendees from all walks of life. It's a vibrant celebration of creativity, bringing people closer to local artists and offering a unique, interactive art experience in a welcoming environment.

Name: Chukwunonso Ofili
Summary: Artbeat HOUSTON is an exciting live art experience where a select group of talented artists are given just one hour to create stunning masterpieces on canvases! As the audience, youll witness the magic unfold before your eyes, with a chance to take home one of these unique creations through a thrilling raffle. Enjoy food and refreshments from local vendors while immersing yourself in the vibrant Houston art scene.

Name: Outspoken Bean
Summary: The presentation will have two key parts. First, animated versions of the poems will be featured on digital sidewalk billboards, bringing the work to life in public spaces. The second part will take place at Brass Tacks coffee shop, where we'll perform and present "Stanzas in Stillness." Along with the live performance, well be giving away free booklets of the project, featuring my poetry and illustrations by Adam Man, offering a creative blend of art and storytelling to the audience.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Outspoken Bean
Summary: Outspoken Bean's "Message by Heir" is a dynamic poetry showcase at 5th Ward's historic Deluxe Theatre. Scheduled for April 8th, 2025, this free performance features headliners Outspoken Bean and Melvin J, alongside talented fifth ward residents. Through storytelling, spoken word, original music, and performance, the event aims to enrich the theater's narrative and celebrate the community's vibrant cultural heritage.

Name: Pluto Soundz
Summary: Pluto Soundz is excited to collaborate with Contempo Arts and Cirque Le Vie for an unforgettable Cabaret at Houstons Saengerbund. This dynamic performance will blend original music, scriptwriting, and acrobatics, offering a unique fusion of artistic styles. Our goal is to captivate and immerse the audience in an extraordinary experience. The show will be held over one weekend in the evenings at Houston Saengerbund in May 2025, with rehearsals and production beginning in January 2025.

Name: Pluto Soundz
Summary: Pluto Soundz is a distinctive string ensemble that fosters community art through concerts blending 20th century techniques with popular music. Born during the pandemic when live performances were rare, we sought to transcend the confines of classical and pop string quartets. Our love for diverse musical styles, including rock and country, inspired us to reimagine the possibilities of a string ensemble.  In our 2024/2025 season we will embark on a series of concerts promoting community engagement and musical exploration through performances at Archway Gallery, The Artique, Fine Instrument Consulting, and more.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Aaron Garrett
Summary: Routine Maintenance is a sci-fi play exploring digital sentience, personal autonomy, and the responsibility going along with that. The story follows an AI running a space station, trapped in its memories while a rogue program destroys the station and its inhabitants. Over the course of the play we see the AI's struggle for respect and basic rights from its users, while it grapples with whether it owes what it never got from humanity to the rogue program. Adapted from an episode of the Houston-based narrative podcast "Space Train," the play premieres in Autumn 2025 at Spring Street Studios.

Name: Public Poetry
Summary: Public Poetry (PP) is a presenting organization that creates general-public programming in Houston, TX. Programs include: a reading series on the first Saturday of each month (2-4 pm) in partnership with the Houston Public Library; a yearly anthology of Houston poets, our 6th coming April 22nd in partnership with Pen and Leaf Press; and REELpoetry, an annual international poetry film festival in its 7th year running March 31st - April 11th (online and at Daley Sports Club). We are expanding our on-demand digital programming with In the Kitchen, a showcase of emerging poets, and Mic Drop, a Houston destination poetry program.

Name: Rothko Chapel
Summary: The Rothko Chapel features programs that weave together art, spirituality, and social justice. We plan to offer multiple programs that will feature art including, but not limited to, our 2025 Martin Luther King Jr. Birthday Observance, focusing on the adverse impacts of the US military economy on our countrys social services, health care system and arts sector; performances from organizations such as DACAMERA, Apollo Chamber Players, Nameless Soul, Ars Lyrica and Sonam Kalra & Sufi Gospel; and performances and art installations from artists such as Samora Pinderhuges and Matthew Shipp.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Theo Chandler
Summary: So You May Breathe In Light" is a new, immersive composition engaging with themes of wellness, healing, and mental health. As someone who has struggled with internalized shame, and who has had the experience of finding self-compassion, I feel it is deeply important to share this story of transformation with audiences in my community. "So You May Breathe In Light" will premiere at MATCH in May 2025.

Name: Ponce Project Foundation
Summary: Five live performances will showcase chamber music and songs by Manuel Ponce and other Latin American composers, including women. The repertoire features chamber music such as trios, sonatas, duets, and "canciones"/songs for various instruments and voices. Performances will take place in Sep/Oct 2025 at Rice University, Moores Opera House, Kinder HSPVA, Steinway Selection Center, and MECA. They will accessible to all as well as live-streamed and recorded. Local and international musicians will participate, with most of the music being newly edited and published by TPP from donated manuscripts.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Amarie Cemone Gipson
Summary: Slated for late June 2025, this two-part program will celebrate the 30th anniversary of bell hooks seminal text Art on My Mind: Visual Politics with a commemorative zine and a film screening. Published by The Reading Room HTX, the zine will illuminate hooks standout ideas on the liberatory power of art and feature sonic, poetic, and visual meditations on the text from invited collaborators. The screening will take place at the DeLUXE Theater and feature an evening of cinematic responses to hooks ideas curated by Amarie Gipson and a host of community partners.

Name: Texas Medical Center Orchestra
Summary: In 2024-25  Texas Medical Center Orchestra (TMCO), will give three full orchestral concerts at Hobby Center and one or two at Miller Outdoor Theatre. Smaller groups of TMCO musicians will give about 15 performances at hospitals, two (livestreamed) at Baylor College of Medicine, and about 20 at retirement homes such as St. Dominic's and Seven Acres. Three dates for Hobby Center are set. Miller Outdoor assigns dates later in the season, and performances at other facilities are arranged on an ad hoc basis.

Name: Uptown Dance Company
Summary: The 2025 season includes over 23 performances with thirteen premiere works in nine unique programs across five different venues throughout greater Houston including: Midtown Arts & Theater Houston, Uptown Dance Center, University of Houston Cullen, Miller Outdoor Theater, Hobby Center, and Royal High School. We are particularly excited about the following projects: Spring is in the Air, Dance Infusion 2025, Wine and Dance, Rocking in the Park (A free event), The Nutcracker Suite, Take Off with Uptown: Celebrating 25 Years, and Fall Fusion 2025. UDC proudly strives to commit to the life of artist who devotes him or herself to dance.

Name: Writers in the Schools
Summary:
Writers in the Schools (WITS) enriches Houston's cultural fabric with year-round literary arts through public performance poetry, open mics, readings, showcases, and multigenerational storytelling. 
A key event is the Young Writers Reading Event on May 3, 2025, at the Menil Collection. Open to the public, this event features poetry performances from creatives showcasing their new work presented to hundreds of attendees, offering a retrospective on WITS programming. From open mics and readings to public showcases and storytelling sessions, WITS fosters a vibrant literary scene in Houston, making literary arts accessible to all and celebrating the city's diversity and influence.

Name: Wordsmyth Theater Company
Summary: Wordsmyth Theater produces a reading series of 6 unproduced, unpublished plays selected from an international call at Main Street Theater (or on Zoom as necessitated by COVID), three in the spring and three in the fall. Each year, we highlight a bilingual play and a play by a Houston playwright. All readings are done with professional actors and directors. The plays are evaluated by theater professionals from around the world, and since our plays were done over Zoom during the pandemic, we took the opportunity to use international actors as well.

Name: 4th Wall Theatre Company
Summary:
4th Wall Theatre Company seeks support for its 14th anniversary season, which includes four professionally produced plays and the educational offering of "Summer Shakes"  a six-week Shakespearean actor training program for Houston-area high school students in collaboration with the Juilliard Drama School. 12-16 public performances of each main-season play will be offered in our 106-seat theatre at Spring Street Studios:
"Swing State" by Rebecca Gilman (Texas Premiere)
"Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike" by Christopher Durang
"Topdog/Underdog" by Suzan-Lori Parks
"Hamlet" by William Shakespeare (Texas Premiere of Acclaimed Off-Broadway Adaptation)
Summer Shakes Showcase (4 performances of Shakespeare play)

Name: Toni Leago Valle
Summary: Toni Valle premieres "Testimony: Epilogue," phase two of a performance response to the sculpture "Witness" by artist Shahzia Sikander.  Phase one, "Testimony: Seen and Heard," addressed the sculptures original intention  to honor the strength and resilience of women and to magnify the importance of feminism and bodily autonomy. After the sculptures brutal beheading during Hurricane Beryl, Sikander has advocated for the sculpture to be seen vandalized as a testament to misogyny and suppression of free speech. Incorporating contemporary dance and aerial to original music by George Heathco, "Testimony: Epilogue" addresses the artists response in the aftermath of the beheading.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Adam Taylor
Summary: We plan on having our first screening at the Secret Group in their box theater. This event will be in March of 2025 and offer the cast crew and the general public the opportunity to see the film. After that initial event we will be submitting the film to First Thursdays, Not Another Film Screening, and Bowl Cuts which are all Houston local screenings, in addition to multiple festivals across Texas and the US.

Name: AFA (American Festival for the Arts)
Summary: As Houston's largest nonprofit provider of music education programs for young people, AFA enriches the lives of 2,000+ students of all backgrounds and skill levels through music each year. AFA's unique and impactful programs culminate in more than 50 recitals and concerts presented free of charge and open to the Greater Houston community in venues across the city.

Name: Ambassadors International Ballet Folklorico
Summary: AIBF plans to produce a large scale folklorico production, free and open to the public, highlighting performances by AIBF folklorico dancers and both local and international latino musical groups. In the past, our events attracted over 1,000 audience members and we expect to continue to increase our audience size with this event and utilize it as a means to widen the exposure of the audience to traditional Hispanic cultures by increasing the range of Latin American countries represented both through dance, wardrobe as well as the musical talent we are able to bring to the stage.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Andrew Roblyer
Summary: LARPing" is a world-premiere play that explores relationships through the lens of roleplaying games and collaborative storytelling. Our plan is to tour this innovative production around Greater Houston, performing in local game and comic book stores. By engaging directly with these vibrant communities, we aim to introduce theatre that resonates with their interests, showing them that their stories matter. Our project not only expands theatrical reach but also cultivates a new audience that feels valued and seen.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Anthony Barilla
Summary: Assemblage..." is a new musical performance piece and composition for three pianos based on the collective works of a wide swath of Houston musicians. The general public will be invited to choose 72 of their favorite songs by Houston artists, which will then be condensed to a few essential melodic elements and, through a predetermined system, layered on top of one another to create a synthesis and celebration of Houston's diverse musical environment performed live on three pianos over a period of three hours in an open air setting at MATCH on November 16, 2025.

Name: APERIO
Summary: Aperio, Music of the Americas is entering its 19th concert season in Houston showcasing the rich diversity of cultures that make our city vibrant, unique, and attractive as a cultural destination. In 2025 the organization will present a world-class public series of ticketed concerts, free events in the community, and impactful outreach experiences scheduled throughout the entire year. To serve a broad audience, Aperio's performances are planned for a variety of venues in Houston's central arts district, outlying areas, and across the state of Texas.

Name: Apollo Chamber Players
Summary: WE THE PEOPLE. Apollo Chamber Players 17th season uplifts the idea of democracy and self-determination through multicultural, multidisciplinary arts programming. As such, Apollo will commission 15 new music and fine arts works and collaborate with 30 locally and nationally-renowned artists of gender and ethnic diversity. Apollos democracy-centered journey includes multiple outreach programs and four main, public-facing concerts: LIBERTY at Zilkha Hall, featuring actor and activist George Takei; OPPORTUNITY at MATCH, featuring dancers from Houston Ballet; DIVERSITY at Zilkha Hall, featuring Iranian composer Reza Vali; and FREEDOM at Holocaust Museum Houston, featuring Kinder HSPVA Choir and Creative Writing students.

Name: Ars Lyrica Houston
Summary: Ars Lyrica Houston (ALH) presents 30+ performances of "Ring in the Peace" at The Buffalo Bayou Park Cistern through December 2025 with additional free performances at Arts District venues such as MECA, Sawyer Yards, and Downtown Houston Tunnels. This multicultural holiday program, curated by Mexican-born mezzo-soprano Cecilia Duarte and Spanish-born percussionist Jess Pacheco, features music for voice and percussion from the ninth century onward. By pairing ancient music with Houstons one-of-a-kind venues, "Ring in the Peace" offers listeners a new, memorable musical experience that fosters reflection and a sense of unity with ones communities, both locally and across the world.

Name: Ars Lyrica Houston
Summary: Ars Lyrica seeks support for all 2025 year programming. Main-stage offerings (at the Hobby Center for the Performing Arts, St. Philip Presbyterian Church, and Rice University) include accompanying digital streams and recordings of six subscription programs plus a collaboration with the UH Moores School of Music on Handel's dramatic oratorio "Theodora." We also offer community and school education outreach programs throughout Houston. For 21 years Ars Lyrica has presented world-class performances of Baroque music in Houston while bringing international attention to the city's thriving arts scene through highly regarded commercial recordings and livestreams.

Name: Bayou City Art Festival
Summary: Art Colony Association, Inc. (ACA) provides multidisciplinary experiences through two outdoor festivals each year (March 28-29 in downtown Houston and October 12-14 in Memorial Park 10am-6pm). The festival promotes visual arts by featuring original art for purchase from artists all over the country, selected through a jury process. We celebrate performing arts on 2 outdoor stages. We feature a culinary arts stage where we spotlight diverse Houston chef's that provide demonstrations to a live audience. We offer free kids arts and crafts in our Active Imagination Zone. We host a craft beer & wine garden and a VIP Hospitality Lounge.

Name: Art League Houston
Summary: Committed to accessibility and inclusiveness, Art League Houston (ALH) is a contemporary visual arts organization that provides programming which engages the community at large and fosters a vibrant network of audiences, students, artists, and patrons. ALH aims to integrate contemporary art into everyday life through an interdisciplinary curatorial approach, which features exhibitions and public programs that reflect our community, as well as extensive educational offerings and community programming which prioritized removing barriers to participation. In 2025, ALH will present 18 public programs and 19 exhibitions, both in-person and virtually, reaching approximately 45,000 participants.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Tami Moschioni
Summary: Art Unitis multi-disciplinary "Bayou Blues" features sculpture, film, dance, and community artworks informed by Fifth Wards Peacock Recording studios history.  Music performances are by local/ regional all-star blues musicians 4-10pm on November 8th at Houstons East River 9 at 65 Hirsch Road. "Fifth Ward Blues" film short showcases African American musicians from the Bronze Peacock Dinner Club with acoustical blues music. Jonn Del Toro Richardsons band accompanies Adam Castanedas modern dance "Peacock Blues" performed to Blues riffs.  Art Uniti unveils "Lightin Blues" rhythmical sculpture with train graffiti. The evening crescendos with a peacock lighting array and an all-star blues stage.

Name: Bay Area Houston Ballet & Theatre
Summary: Bay Area Houston Ballet is the only non-profit semi-professional ballet company on the south side of Houston that creates triple threat dancers, and an eclectic season that entices diversified audiences.  Four full staged productions are done each year bringing over 15,000 to the theater and thousands to attend our public events.  Numerous outreach endeavors are done yearly in schools, parks, and events to promote the arts to our community.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Christian Betirri
Summary: Following the origin of my artistic journey, which it combines the passion for soccer and art, I am preheating and revamping for the evolution of my artistic practice through a series of events and projects that will lead to the celebration of the 2026 World Cup in Houston. These events consist of screenings of historic World Cup games during the mornings and afternoons of various Saturdays at different cultural spaces, exhibitions supporting younger artists with evening receptions at my gallery and at soccer academies, and panel discussions from local sports leaders during the evenings at cultural hubs.

Name: Michele Brangwen Dance Ensemble
Summary: We will create a new contemporary dance and music film entitled "Art Deco," that tributes the life and music of the legendary jazz trumpeter and composer Don Cherry. The film will premiere at the Deluxe Theater, as part of a concert of Don Cherrys music by the MBDME musicians: Grammy-Nominated trumpeter & composer Tim Hagans; bassist and composer Thomas Helton; drummer Sam Knight; and special guest vocalist and pianist Angela Wang. After becoming famous by playing with Texas saxophonist Ornette Coleman, Cherry traveled to Europe, the Far East and Africa, incorporating many different cultural musical influences into his composing and performing.

Name: Brave Little Company
Summary: In 2024-25, Brave Little Company will create two world premieres, LOST LUGGAGE (immersive theatre in a suitcase for ages 8-13 and their families) at MATCH and other venues in January-February 2025, and WILDEST DREAMS, a meditation on diaspora, freedom, and wildness for ages 4-8 and their families at library venues in June 2025. We will also remount performances of GRANDPAS GARDEN, our sensory chamber musical, in November 2024. We will continue two of our major initiatives, Our Stories Belong community reading and arts workshops, and THE BIG "US" PROJECT, a collaborative theatre project created by members of Houstons refugee communities.

Name: Britt Thomas
Summary: In Lieu of" is an outdoor solo art exhibition at Lawndale Art Center's sculpture garden in 2025. Featuring participatory and site-specific artworks with a droll funerary aesthetic, the exhibit critiques the inadequacies of modern sympathy in a social media-driven world where public expressions of grief are often performative and overly scrutinized.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Britt Thomas
Summary: Press is a powerful public art performance that underscores the immense risks journalists face globally, especially in conflict zones. Granite grave markers engraved with "PRESS" are repeatedly pressed into the soil of Houston's public parks, leaving poignant impressions destined to weather away. Experience this impactful statement on press freedom during performances on October 26 and November 16 at 11:00 am, and November 19, 2025, at 5:00 pm, coinciding with International Journalists Remembrance Day.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Jordan Lumpkins
Summary: The Price of Freedom" is an art exhibition running from February 1-28, in observance of Black History Month. This powerful event will explore the journey to equality for people of color post-Jim Crow Era in America, featuring visual art and live performances by local artists. The exhibition will provide a platform for unique talents and perspectives, celebrating the resilience and creativity of the community.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Carla Lyles
Summary: Momma Loves Jazz, is an immersive art exhibit by Carla Lyles, curated by the Anderson Center of the Arts. Running from June 7th to July 26th, 2025, at the Community Artists Collective in Houston, TX, this exhibit explores the profound journey of maternal healing through jazz music, art and interactive installations. Inspired by the connection Carla and her mother shared through jazz, the exhibit reflects jazz has been a source of comfort, communication, and healing in their relationship. We invite visitors to reflect on their own relationships and the unifying power of local music and art.

Name: Chinese Community Center
Summary: Commemorating the Year of the Snake, the 2025 Lunar New Year Festival will celebrate one of the most important holidays in Chinese and many Asian cultures by featuring traditional musical, dance, and martial arts performances; a festive bazaar with games, vendor giveaways, and mouth-watering cuisine from local restaurants and food trucks; and hands-on cultural activities for all ages, such as origami and Chinese calligraphy. The festival will take place on Saturday, February 1, 2025, from 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. at the Chinese Community Center, located at 9800 Town Park Drive in the heart of southwest Houstons Asiatown.

Name: Chamber Music Houston
Summary: Chamber Music Houston inspires a passion for chamber music in Houston and worldwide by presenting exceptional chamber music ensembles performing diverse programs, ranging from classical favorites to new works by composers of today. This year features 10 public, ticketed concerts in Stude Concert Hall on the Rice University campus. There will be musicians from France, Israel, Germany, Great Britain, Canada and the United States. Houstonians and listeners beyond can enjoy 12 FREE digital concerts in the cmh@home series. Also, CMH will deliver 15 FREE Outreach performances and masterclasses, and 40 FREE private music lessons to economically challenged young people.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Chelsea de Souza
Summary: In October 2025 at Midtown Arts and Theater Center Houston (MATCH), Indian pianist Chelsea de Souza will premiere a new jazz-inspired piano concerto by Korean composer Nicky Sohn, with local contemporary classical ensemble Loop38. Created through a unique process of collaboration between soloist and composer, the concerto will be influenced by aspects of jazz and funk like improvisation and groove, highlighting the musical and cultural diversity of both Houston and the artists involved. By bringing the energy and hype of our Spotify playlists to the concert hall, we hope to connect with a wide range of audiences.

Name: Houston Cinema Arts Society
Summary: Houston Cinema Arts Society will present two annual flagship programs: the Houston Media Conference in August, focused on professional development for filmmakers, and the Houston Cinema Arts Festival (HCAF) in November. HCAF2025 will consist of over 60 film events throughout the city, focusing on the diverse cultural communities of Houston and stories that reflect their experiences. HCAF also includes CineSpace, a short film competition in collaboration with NASA, and the Borders | No Borders competition for emerging filmmakers from Texas and surrounding regions. HCAS is driven to develop an equitable, sustainable film industry that benefits the city both artistically and economically.

Name: Children's Museum of Houston
Summary: With our year-round, bilingual programming we engage families of children ages 0-12 in hands-on, participatory experiences that feature dance, film, literature, music, performing arts, theater, visual arts, craft, multimedia, and design/fabrication. Understanding that arts and cultural experiences are essential to childrens socioemotional and cognitive development, we ensure that families can participate fully regardless of financial constraints and language barriers. We provide free admission for 40% of Museum visitors and facilitate 100% of outreach programming free of charge for participants. In FY24 we served 700,000 Museum visitors and 140,00 outreach participants at 345 locations in under-resourced neighborhoods across Greater Houston.

Name: Houston Center for Contemporary Craft
Summary: Since 2001, Houston Center for Contemporary Craft (HCCC) has established itself as an important cultural and artistic resource for Houston and the nationone of the few venues in the country dedicated to the interpretation and presentation of craft at the highest level. In service of its mission to advance education on the process, product, and history of craft, HCCC is committed to providing free admission to its exhibitions and programming, while supporting artists who make the field possible. HCCC hosts resident artists, exhibitions, and an ongoing schedule of educational initiatives in its 11,350-square-foot facility located within the Houston Museum District.

Name: Creativity Shell
Summary: On Saturday, April 5, 2025, the Creativity Shell will host our 10th annual "Creativity Rocks" student fashion show and creative community event!  This event will feature 200+ students showcasing their handmade creations and rocking their unique designs down a runway in front of 1000+ people!  Throughout the Creativity Rocks weekend, creative artists from all across the country will be invited to gather and sell their unique creations with the student fashion show being the highlight of the weekend.

Name: DACAMERA
Summary: In 2025, DACAMERA will present seventy chamber music and jazz concerts of the highest caliber to the Houston community, in venues such as the Wortham Theater Center, the Menil Collection, The Hobby Center for the Performing Arts, and public spaces such as libraries, hospitals, and museums. DACAMERAs Education and Community Initiatives department will provide arts-integrated lessons in HISD schools, free community concerts, and provide professional development through the Young Artist program. All told, DACAMERA will reach 30,000 Houstonians and cultural tourists through transformative musical experiences.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Diane Gelman
Summary: EAT! will be a visual feast and delicious celebration of original art about food.  EAT! will feature a showcase of imaginative food-centric paintings, exciting food sculptures, and site specific food-based installations.  It will be held in Gallery 200, The Silos, date and time TBD.  I would submit this Exhibition for a 6 week event, including a public presentation on the second Saturday of the month at 5 PM.

Name: Diaz Music Institute
Summary: The 25th Annual Latin Jazz Summer Workshop and Concert Series is a multi-week city-wide program for students ages 4-18 held during June - August at Bayland Community Center (District J), MacArthur HS, Waltrip HS (District C), Wheatley HS (District B), Raul Yzaguirre School for Success (District I), and Lakeshore Elementary (District E) in Houston, TX. Participants have courses in theory, music business, production, improvisation, dance, and masterclasses on their instruments. The workshop exposes students to diverse cultures through instructors, artists, music, and concert performances. Concerts are free and held in Houston's parks and other venues in historically marginalized communities.

Name: Dirt Dogs Theatre Co.
Summary: Dirt Dogs Theatre Co. continues to produce thought-provoking, discussion-starting theatre through our recently announced Season 9 lineup, consisting of three mainstage productions and our annual Student Playwright Festival. RACE runs October 18 - November 2, 2024, BLACKBIRD plays February 28 - March 8, 2025, and BUG performs May 16 - 31, 2025. The 7th Student Playwright Festival debuts three world premiere plays by Houston-area high school seniors on May 28, 2025. All events take place at MATCH  Midtown Arts and Theater Center Houston.

Name: Discovery Green Conservancy
Summary: Discovery Green is like a free outdoor cultural center in the heart of downtowns convention and visitors district showcasing arts programming reflective of Houstons diversity. Its three curated seasons offer visitors opportunities to engage and explore art in a free and relaxed atmosphere. From temporary and permanent public art, live concerts, diverse cultural performances, art workshops, and films, and community celebrations, Discovery Green's programming is often many peoples' first encounter with an art form - creating lasting memories and new friendships. They are also many visitors' and conventioneers' first impression of Houston, making it a unique cultural ambassador for our city.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Murad Aliyev
Summary: The General" is fourth episode of 3D animated series "The Man from Oghuz". Loosely based on Turkic epic medieval legends, series tells a story of a young man sent to foreign soil to fulfill his fathers orders. It is a coming of age story dealings with moral and ethic values, and acceptance. 40 minute episode is a fourth episode in the series. First and second episodes were produced with help of HAA (SACI recipient 2020/21 and SACI 2023) and third one is currently in production (SACI 2024). Project is culturally significant for Turkish, Azerbaijani, Kazakh and Turkmen communities in Houston.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Elisabeth Ellison
Summary: With my ensemble "Old Spanish Trail", I am re-creating concerts and performances from the early days of Houston and our region - pre-1900. This is a vital part of Houston's history. We will present classical music and folk/popular styles of the era, closely following documented original performances.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Elizabeth Newkirk
Summary: The Archetype of Modern Man (season 2) is a 4-part multi-disciplinary series that explores tropes of the modern human condition. Musicians, philosophers and visual artists come together, expressing different facets of the theme for each presentation. Taking place at the Steinway Selection Center in downtown Houston, this series puts the humanities into practice, creating an opportunity for a shared public reflection.

Name: Erin Rodgers
Summary: Event: National Pleasure Album release/listening party, with accompanying printed art map, and collaborative community map. When: Late May, 2025. Where: TBD, but will be held at a centrally located space that allows early evening events and has no age restriction.

Name: Fifth Ward Community Redevelopment Corporation
Summary: This grant supports the work of the 5th Ward Cultural Arts District managed by the Fifth Ward Community Redevelopment Corporations. Our Artistic programs include the Historic DeLUXE Theater, The DeLUXE K!Dds youth musical theater and violin programs, Black Theater Week, The Lyons Avenue Renaissance Festival, The DeLUXE Village affordable housing complex for artists and Artist in residence program (13 cottages), The 5th Ward Minin-Music Museum, and several publi art projects.

Name: Friends of River Oaks Theatre
Summary:
We curate and run regular Public Film/Art Programs at museums, parks, and historic(?) theatre(s). Next up 7/26/24 Monty Python "Quote-A-Long" screening with live music by Jukebox Trainwreck. Doors 7pm, film 8:15 at MATCH. Our semi-monthly podcast, Friends on Film, features: 
Interviewswith a Director/Actor 
Arthouse RevivalNational arthouse leaders talk about fun programs
PopsAmusing and inspired stories about working in an arthouse
Creative MischiefArtists, Organizations, Performers, tied to local programming.
CalendarWhat's up? Houston film community.

We do Preservation efforts for historic theatres

We make and do calls for Original Artist Work, both film projects and musical scores.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Ichikara Valdez
Summary: Making the Brand" is a documentary that examines the transformation of independent artists into reputable brands through local collaboration and curation. Featuring artists such as musician Ichikara Valdez, aesthetic curator Carlos Casteneria, and others, it highlights their work in set design, live performance, merchandise, and marketing.
