The film seeks to capture their challenges and successes, while showcasing the dedication and inter-community support behind their achievements. Production starts in early 2025, with a premiere on December 12, 2025 in Houstons East End.

Name: Hayan Charara
Summary: RAWIFest showcases Arab, North African, and Southwest Asian writers, artists, filmmakers, and scholars from around the country and world. Open to the public, the 3-day event features readings, panel discussions, interviews, exhibits, and workshops. A bi-annual event, RAWI Fest will be held in October 2025 at the University of Houston, as well as off-site venues like Poison Girl, Brazos Bookstore, and other locations. It is our goal to make this event as accessible as possible and to pay every panelist and reader an honorarium, so that neither physical nor financial need will present a barrier for participation.

Name: The Heritage Society
Summary: With HAA funding, for our 70th Anniversary, THS plans to present a dynamic series of programs, including National Heritage Days, and Homeschool Fieldtrip Days. Guided by our Education Manager, with a Master of Arts in History, Rice University, these programs, delivered in-person and online, will engage children and adults through hands-on activities. Fun and educational Arts elements include song, dance, crafts, acting in historic houses, and monthly speakers. On-site programs with paid guest artists will serve more than 1,000 youth and several I.S.D.s, including Title 1, public, private and homeschool groups; along with THS members, public tours, and seniors.

Name: HITS Theatre
Summary: Programs will serve over 1,100 acting, voice, dance, and technical theater students over the course of a year. Over 4,000 visitors attend 30-40 live performances and cultural events at free or affordable admission prices. As HITS launches programming and outreach to engage community members of all ages, we look forward to deepening our relationships within Greater Heights. HITS Theatre delivers quality performing arts education accessible to all students regardless of financial status. HITS provides tuition scholarships to any student who applies. The need for assistance continues to grow and a record $40,000 in scholarships were awarded in 2024.

Name: CCM Foundation
Summary: The Clutch City Art Project(CCAP), formerly known as Art On The Streets, which is one of the largest annual public exhibitions of youth art in Houston/Harris County, is slated to have installations at four (4) Houston Health Department Multi-Service Center locations throughout Houston in 2024 and 2025. Since 2025 celebrates CCAP's 10th year of raising awareness on HIV/AIDS through visual arts, we'd like to expand the reach and visibility of the project in 2025 by featuring the Grand Prize-winning artists' artwork on a billboard and incentivizing artists that standout in featured categories of the project.

Name: Holocaust Museum Houston
Summary: Exhibitions with programs include "The Bias Inside Us" (9/13 to 10/6/2024) will help people understand and counter their biases, convene dialogue in communities, and inspire more inclusive schools, communities, and workplaces. "Caribbean Indigenous Resistance" (11/1 to 1/12/2025) presents the history of the Tanos, Indigenous peoples of the northern Caribbean islands, and how their descendants are reaffirming their culture and identity today. "Life and Death on the Border 1910-1920" (1/23 to 5/25/2025) reveals steps Mexican Americans took to fight for their civil rights and use artistic expression to bring attention to their cause. Fall 2025, photographer Cynthia Isaksons exhibition "Anachronous" opens.

Name: The Houston Museum of Natural Science
Summary: HMNS requests operational support to help deliver immersive educational experiences to the city of Houston. Founded in 1909, HMNS has been a powerful force for science education for more than a century. Its size and scope of programming has catapulted it into the top tier of the nations museums, consisting of 433,000 square feet of exhibition spaces, the Burke Baker Planetarium, Wortham Giant Screen Theatre, and Cockrell Butterfly Center. It has a rich history of hosting traveling exhibits and is a beloved resource for education through its field trips, summer camps, outreach programming, educator workshops, and growing digital library.

Name: Houston Ballet
Summary: Commencing in 2024, Houston Ballets 55th season will continue into 2025 featuring full-length ballets like the Houston premiere of The Little Mermaid, and premiere works from emerging creators Japanese-American choreographer Brett Ishida and Black choreographer Silas Farley along with welcoming back Colombian-Belgian choreographer Annabelle Lopez Ochoa fall 2025. Of course, included is the annual 35+ show run of the blockbuster production The Nutcracker bringing over 75,000 people to the Houston Theater District this holiday season. Dance Talks  live conversations with dancers, choreographers, and designers  and Virtual Field Trips  free, introductory video experiences to dance  will continue.

Name: Houston Black Heritage Music & Arts Fest
Summary: Join us on November 14-15, 2025 at Peggy Park for the 9th annual Black Heritage Fest (BHF).  Explore a diverse array of cultural exhibits that showcase the rich history of African Americans in Hosuton and beyond at BHF focusing on Black Arts .  Local artisans will display their crafts while food vendors offer delicious traditional cuisine that reflects our heritage.  This is not just and event; it is a platform for local musicians, artists, small business exhibitors, fashion designers who share a passion for uplifting the black community.

Name: Houston Brass Quintet
Summary: Over the past year, Houston Brass Quintet has made significant growth in not only community support, income, demand for bookings and ability to sponsor flagship concerts but also growth in the need for marketing and administrative/organizational support. In order to meet HBQs growth rates and continue providing Houston with diverse music HBQ would be able to use this grant to extend their contract with their social media manager, hire Sarah and Russell to work part-time to fulfill the necessary administrative needs and sponsor additional diverse flagship concerts.

Name: Houston Children's Chorus
Summary:
Our annual Presidents' Day Winter Luncheon ( a free luncheon fundraiser), Monday, February 17, 2025, 11:30AM, Junior League of Houston. Reservations required.
"Spring Concert", Sunday, May 4, 2025, 5:00PM, Brockman Hall for Opera, Rice University, World Premiere of a major work commissioned by HCC, 150 singers accompanied by orchestra.
"Mahler's Third Symphony", Friday thru Sunday, May 30 thru June 1, 2025, Jones Hall (Houston Symphony performance).
"Kids & Christmas" Pops Concert, Saturday, December 13, 2025, 5:00PM, Stude Concert Hall, Rice University. (tentative date).
"Concert of Sacred Christmas", Sunday, December 14, 2025, 4:00PM & 6:00PM, Chapel of Villa De Matel Convent (tentative date).

Name: Houston Grand Opera
Summary: Featuring popular musicals, bestsellers, and rare gems, Houston Grand Opera's 2025 season will draw over 55,000 people to the Houston Theater District, with 25% coming from outside Houston. From January through December 2025, HGO will present Bernsteins iconic West Side Story, Puccinis beloved La bohme, Missy Mazzolis buzzy Breaking the Waves, Wagners rarely performed Tannhuser, Gershwins genre-defying Porgy and Bess, and Puccinis rarely performed Il Trittico, which can only be seen in Houston. In addition to the downtown mainstage season, HGO will reach another 60,000 people through community and learning programs across Houston next year.

Name: Houston Latin American Philharmonic
Summary:
These are exciting times for the Houston Latin American Philharmonic, the only full-size professional orchestra in the United States created to promote and elevate Latin American music. The Houston Latin Phil celebrates its 13th anniversary with four gala concerts as follows: Mother's Day Serenade on May 9 - 8:00 pm; Nostalgia on June 21-8:00 pm; Viva Latin America on October 11 - 8:00 pm; and Latin Christmas on December 5 - 8:00 pm. Led by maestro Garrido, the HLAP is comprised by 52
professional musicians performing traditional rhythms like Tango, Ranchera, Bolero and more -music that makes you dance even in your seats!

Name: Houston Symphony
Summary: The oldest and most established performing arts organization in the city, the Houston Symphony engages more than 400,000 individuals through our artistic programming, education programs, and our community engagement initiatives each season. During our 2024-25 Season, we celebrate our 111th Season with a planned 19 Classical concert weekends, nine POPS concert weekends, 12 Symphony Specials, five concerts at Cynthia Woods Mitchell Pavilion, six concerts at Miller Outdoor Theatre, five chamber concerts, four Family Series concerts, three Community Concerts, and concerts in under resourced communities throughout Houston as part of our Neighborhood Concert Series.

Name: Houston Youth Symphony
Summary: Houston Youth Symphony's nationally acclaimed Youth Orchestra Program offers professional performances year-round in Greater Houston. Featuring 5 orchestras, we present Fall Concerts on October 20, 2024, at Rice Universitys Stude Concert Hall (2:30pm, 7:00pm); Winter Concerts on February 9, 2025, at the same venue (11:30am, 3:30pm); and Spring Concerts on May 4, 2025, at University of Houstons Moores Opera House (2:30pm, 7:00pm). HYS also presents the Concerto Competition Winners and Chamber Music Recital on May 10, 2025, at UHs Dudley Recital Hall (4:00pm), and the Coda/WindSync end-of-year collaboration on April 11, 2025 at Strake Jesuit College Preparatorys Parsley Center.

Name: Houston Palestine Film Festival
Summary: The Houston Palestine Film Festival (HPFF) offers the Houston community an opportunity to learn about the people, culture and art of Palestine through a diverse selection of short films, features, and documentaries. For 17 consecutive years, we have partnered with the broader community to bring a wide variety of Palestinian films to Houston, and have screened films at the Museum of Fine Arts Houston (MFAH) and Rice Cinema. Typically, the festival takes place over two weekends in mid-April for a total of six days of screening. Planned weeks are April 1113 and Aprill 1820, 2025.

Name: Italian Cultural & Community Center of Houston
Summary: We offer over 50 educational/cultural programs at the Milford House, including a Contemporary Italian Film Series, wine tastings, cooking classes for children, diverse lectures, and cultural enrichment classes. The ICCC also offers Italian language classes for adults and children, and special courses for travelers and conversational Italian. Cultural Enrichment classes include art history, literature, opera, mosaics, and more. We will be holding our sixth annual Italian Fashion Show and Luncheon in 2025. Many of our events are free to the public including a yearly Open House where people can come experience a little bit of Italy in Houston.

Name: India House Houston
Summary: India House, a non-profit organization dedicated to serving Greater Houston through various charity and welfare initiatives, also celebrates Indian arts, culture, and heritage. We are pleased to announce that our Diwali celebration, the Celebration of Lightsa commemoration of the triumph of good over evilwill be tentatively held on November 2nd, 2025. The event will take place on our expansive 9.6-acre outdoor premises and within our 30,000-square-foot building. This celebration will feature dancers, musicians, visual artists, and vendors. We are thrilled to share the joy of Diwali with Houstonians from all walks of life!

Name: Inprint
Summary: Inprints public presentations attract diverse audiences and feature an inclusive array of leading authors in four distinct series: Inprint Margarett Root Brown Reading Series (Mondays), Inprint Cool Brains! Series (Sundays), Inprint Escritores en la casa Series (Fridays), and Inprint Ink Well podcast. Readings take place at Houstons top performance venues and expand author/audience engagement in and beyond Houston. Inprint also offers writers workshops for aspiring authors, and citywide community workshops for seniors, K-12 teachers, healthcare providers, veterans, and the incarcerated at Harris County Jail. All are offered free or low cost and provide support and teaching experience to local authors.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Jose Antonio Diaz
Summary: Play, Learn, Growth" is the title of a collection of children's songs I will create to capture life experiences from the perspective of a child. This work seeks to musically capture the emotions involved in the life experiences of children, especially BIPOC kids, and how they learn to navigate living in the world today. Performances will feature artists of various ages and genders. "Play, Learn, Growth" will be performed live for free at four marginalized communities in Houston.

Name: The Jung Center
Summary: The Jung Center offers a wide range of public, collaborative arts programming to the public. Throughout the year, these programs use the arts to support mental health - a strategy that happens in the community, rather than in clinics, and that is unique to The Jung Center. Our Community for Conscious Aging is a growing resource providing an inclusive learning community for seniors seeking vitality, purpose, wisdom, and grace. The CCAs new Afternoon Art Salons offer monthly free, public forums for art exploration and conversations on creativity and aging.

Name: The Jung Center
Summary: The Jung Center offers a wide range of public, interactive arts programs supporting the mental health of more than 30,000 people each year - a strategy unique to our organization. Influenced by psychiatrist Carl Jungs insight that creativity is necessary for mental health, classes, performances, and exhibitions happen at our Museum District building, with partner organizations in the community, and online  making mental health resources accessible outside of the clinic. Led by artists, writers, musicians, psychotherapists, and spiritual teachers, multidisciplinary programs focus on ways arts create community, fulfilling the basic human need to express emotion and share experiences and values.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Katrina Moorhead
Summary: Tender / Not All Green Books Contain Arsenic is an assembly of visual artworks and activity which will thoughtfully illustrate various definitions of the word tender'. For example, to tend - someone who nurtures something or someplace; or to offer or present; or an exchange; or marked by, responding to, or expressing the softer emotions. Programming will occur in and close to Inman Gallerys new exhibition space on Alabama Street in September - October 2025. The presentation is two-pronged in that there will be a cabinet of changing items along with an exhibition of sculptural objects and works on paper.

Name: Kenya Anais
Summary: Kenya Anais is launching her brand, KA, with a prestigious event in Houstons vibrant Third Ward on March 22nd at El Dorado from 2pm to 6pm. This showcase will blend art, fashion, and design, emphasizing local culture and community, featuring an art & fashion show where local models will strut down the runway adorned in KAs distinctive artwork, apparel, accessories, and shoes. Luxurious commercials and brand ambassadors aim to highlight KAs commitment to creativity and excellence. We'll highlight Third Wards artistic spirit as a catalyst for ongoing collaborations and community engagement, elevating Houstons status as a hub of artistic innovation.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Lanre Buraimoh
Summary:
Houston Harmony: Celebrating Cultural Diversity,  This exhibition features an array of glass bead artworks and paintings that capture the essence of cultural diversity and unity. Each piece is a vibrant expression of different cultural stories and traditions, meticulously crafted using glass beads and paint to add depth and texture. The paintings, rich in color and symbolism, explore themes of community, identity, and shared humanity. Through this exhibition, I aim to engage audience 
 of cultural advocate and community members of all ages in a visual dialogue, celebrating the beauty of diversity and the common threads that connect us all.

Name: Danza Azteca
Summary: On August 16, 2025, 4pm - 9pm, Danza Azteca Taxcayolotl will host their annual Danza Azteca ceremony to honor the resistance of the indigenous people of Mexico-Tenochtitlan. Experience the vibrant performances of over 100 dancers from across the United States, dressed in colorful regalia and headdresses adorned with beautiful long feathers, as they pay tribute to generations of indigenous traditions. Held in Houstons historic Second Ward at Eastwood Park, the event will feature traditional Mesoamerican instruments, creating rhythms for ceremonial dancing. Enjoy vendors, food, and family-friendly activities as we celebrate and preserve this rich cultural heritage.

Name: Lawndale Art and Performance Center
Summary: Since 1979, Lawndale has filled a vital space in Houston (the most ethnically diverse city in the United States,) as an incubator for exhibitions, performances, and conversations, encompassing a breadth of perspectives. Lawndale is committed to supporting artist-driven, non-hierarchical programing including the visual arts, sound and performance, literary readings, and more with a focus on artists at critical moments in their careers from Houston and the Gulf Coast region. Our year-round programmingalways free + open to the publicengages the intricacies of contemporary culture by representing a diverse range of artistic voices reflective of Houstons expanding global population.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Liyen Chong
Summary: Discover "Gardens of Delight," a transformative series inspired by Robin Wall Kimmerer's "Braiding Sweetgrass", and Ross Gays "Inciting Joy". Immerse yourself in nature's ancestral wisdom as we explore joy and community healing through a collaborative artistic project between Liyen Chong, Eddie Garcia, and Alba Donajhi Sereno, featuring Houstons lush ecosystem. Taking cues from diasporic and Indigenous identities, seasonal events invite you to reconnect with land, cultivate inner growth, and celebrate profound bonds between nature and well-being. Join us to experience art through insightful discussions and nurturing rituals that honor our roots to foster a deep, restorative connection with the earth.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Lizbeth Ortiz
Summary: I am proposing the creation of the Tree of Commemoration, an interactive and poignant community sculpture dedicated to honoring the memory of our departed loved ones. This installation will be featured at MECAs Day of the Dead Festival, taking place on November 1st and 2nd 2025, located at 1900 Kane St., Houston, TX 77007. We can honor our past, embrace our present, and inspire our future. Through this sculpture, I aim to provide a meaningful space for collective remembrance, reflection, and cultural celebration. By engaging the community in its creation, we can foster a sense of connection and shared purpose.

Name: Main Street Theater
Summary: In 2025, Main Street Theater will present five MainStage productions at our Rice Village location and six Theater for Youth (TY) productions at Midtown Arts and Theater Center.  Each production will have four to five week run of public performances.  At Rice Village, highlights will be the world premiere of Dain Geist's dark comedy SEVEN ASSASSINS WALK INTO A BAR,  KIM'S CONVENIENCE, THE 39 STEPS, and Tom Stoppard's LEOPOLDSTADT.  At MATCH, our professional TY will open the year with THE LIGHTNING THIEF, THE PERCY JACKSON MUSICAL, followed by  DIARY OF A WIMPY KID and THE WIND IN THE WILLOWS.

Name: Margaux Crump
Summary: As a triad of complementary community events including an art exhibition, boat tour, and guided bayou ecology walk in spring of 2025, "Mother Bayou" provides a much-needed opportunity to empower everyday Houstonians to cultivate more meaningful relationships with the dynamic, yet often-overlooked waters that shape and animate our city. This collaborative project by visual artists Margaux Crump and Jake Eshelman wonders what might be possible when we collectively reimagine Houston's bayou system as a sacred, fertile community space that nurtures the biodiversity, vitality, and unfolding story of our city.

Name: Mercury Chamber Orchestra
Summary: Mercury's 2025 Downtown Series features seven concerts performed at the Wortham Center. The first half of 2025 will include: Vivaldi, Handel, & Bach (1/11/25); Loving Clara Schumann (2/8-2/9/25); Bach's St. John Passion (3/22/25); and Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto (5/17/25). Mercury's Neighborhood Series features three contrasting programs held at four distinct and intimate venues: Museum of Fine Arts Houston, Saengerhalle, Memorial Drive Presbyterian Church, and Dosey Doe in The Woodlands. Spring 2025 will include The Art of Joropo: Venezuelan Folk Music (4/10-4/13/25) with Venezuelan violinist Alexis Cardenas. The programming for the latter half of 2025 will be finalized in November 2024.

Name: Mildred's Umbrella Theater Company
Summary: Mildred's Umbrella is requesting funding to produce our 2025 season of 2 full productions and one Latina play reading series. We are in negotiations to utilize the empty black box theatre at the Evelyn Rubenstien JCC to produce 2 new plays by female playwrights. There will be one full production in Spring and one in Fall. We are also negotiating with Latinx organizations, including MECA to produce readings of 3 new plays by Latina playwrights in the Summer of 2025.   All productions will continue to support our mission to provide opportunities for female playwrights and theatre artists.

Name: Foundation for Modern Music
Summary: Foundation for Modern Music (FMM) exists to bring high-quality music with a message to the widest possible audiences. While we embrace some of most technically challenging/controversial premieres in the city, we refuse to be "stuffy" or limited to one tradition. Founded 1986, concerts began at one location - initially averaging 300 yearly. FMM now presents citywide concerts in many venues (MATCH, MFAH, Miller Outdoor Theatre, Zilkha Hall, etc.) with annual attendance growing to 10,000+ the past four seasons! Culturally diverse programming and artists, with extensive cross-disciplinary collaborations, reflect values Houston celebrates - this richness of diversity drives our day-to-day philosophy and operations.

Name: MUSIQA
Summary: Musiqa will commission new music from Houston composer Theo Chandler celebrating and exploring the Vietnamese communitys historical and ongoing impact on Midtown. This neighborhood was the first Vietnamese business district in Houston but has been dramatically reshaped by gentrification and migration during the 2000s. Chandlers composition for voice and string trio will be inspired and informed by interviews with members of the Vietnamese community still residing in the area, will feature collaboration with local civic groups, and will conclude with a performance on the evening of December 13, 2025 at Lawndale Art Center in Midtown.

Name: Nigerian-American Multicultural Council
Summary: The Festival of African Arts, Culture, and Entertainment--Houston AfriFEST--is a yearly festival celebrating the rich cultures of Africa in Houston in a family-friendly, open-air format hosted by a number of partnering African organizations, led by the Nigerian-American Multicultural Council. Houston AfriFEST invites Houstonians of all backgrounds and guests from out of town to enjoy a space where they can "Experience Africa" through all of the senses.  It features diverse food, kids educational activities, entertainment, and cultural enrichment experiences through the unique peoples in the Africa Zone.  It is held from 11am to 7 pm on a Saturday in October, 2025.

Name: Nameless Sound
Summary: Nameless Sound will present over 34 concerts through two series. They, Who Sound features 27 Monday events (January 13 - December 15, with a Summer break) at Lawndale Art Center, each with two distinct performances. It includes national and international artists, but centers Houston performers. The Creative Music Concert Series features more than seven concerts of international artists including: Tomeka Reid (January 31, ElDorado Ballroom), Brighde Chaimbeul (March 26, MATCH), James Brandon Lewis/Floy Krouchi (April 25, DeLuxe Theater), Okkyung Lee (May 3, MATCH), Matthew Shipp (June 21, Rothko Chapel), Wadada Leo Smith/Amina Claudine Myers (September 20, El Dorado Ballroom).

Name: NobleMotion Dance
Summary: Emerging technologies influence two new evening-length productions for NobleMotions 17th season. In "What's the Score," NMD explores the neurobiology of creativity through a partnership with neuroscientist Jose Contreras-Vidal and composer Anthony Brandt. This performance/science experiment maps the impact of creativity on the brain, continuing important advocacy for the arts. Dancers and musicians will wear EEG caps as real-time data visualizations contrast rehearsed and improvising minds. Performances will take place at the MATCH and Discovery Series. In August, NobleMotion presents "Minus the Bones" at the MATCH, a collaboration with composer/multimedia artist Badie Khaleghian that examines evolving issues with AI technology governance.

Name: OCA-Greater Houston
Summary: OCA-GH is a community builder empowering Asian American and Pacific Islanders through civic participation. We organize arts and cultural programs and events that raise awareness of AAPI stories and contributions to inspire our community to become more civically engaged citizens and social justice advocates. To achieve our mission, we organize year-round arts cultural programming to achieve our mission through our annual June HAAPIFEST, quarterly HAAPI Hour/Tea Talks, AAPI Restaurant Weeks, and fall Starry Nite Arts Festival. Each of our low-cost and free programs aims to provide inclusive events to learn, connect, and engage with Houstons diverse AAPI community members.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Bevin Biggers
Summary: Bevin Biggers plans to create an editorial cocktail book that reclaims southern cocktail-making for the Black American audience. Through bold and luminous imagery, it will attract all audiences, but I hope to inspire the often-neglected demographic in the southern hospitality industry. I will do this by including well-studied and practiced literary knowledge, creative storytelling through vibrant photography, and the art of cocktail making. I plan to showcase the book at local Houston Bookstores and Bars in December 2025.

Name: Open Dance Project
Summary: Our 2025 10th Anniversary Season includes: "The Wonderful Wizard of Oz" for family audiences Jan 24-Feb 2, with free student matinees and sensory friendly performances at MATCH and The Hobby Center; the reimagining of ODPs immersive productions "Panopticon" May 1-10 and "DADA GERT" Nov 7-22 at MATCH, two of ODPs earliest and most foundational immersive works; and the launch of the "Immersive Access Initiative," providing staff development, pilot community engagement programs, technical resources and training, accessibility support, and targeted marketing to communities with disabilities in the context of a radical access vision for Open Dance Projects next ten years.

Name: Orange Show Center for Visionary Art
Summary: OSCVA will present a season of arts programing including tours and events at its three world-famous artist-built environments and one recently accessioned collection: The Orange Show, The Beer Can House, and Smither Park, and the Hyde Park Miniature Museum. Funds will also support the annual Art Car Parade in downtown Houston in April and the fourth annual Art Bike Parade at MacGregor Park in May.

Name: Performing Arts Houston
Summary: Performing Arts Houston's 2025 programming is expected to draw over 50,000 audience members over two artistic seasons: the spring of the 24/25 Season and the fall of the 25/26 Season. Spring 2025 presentations include 17 performances by touring and local artists and companies representing a variety of performing arts genres at multiple Theater District venues, along with 30 public learning programs delivered both independently and in collaboration with touring artists. Fall 2025 programming will be announced in April 2025, but is expected to include approximately 20 additional mainstage presentations and 30 public programs.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: William Guaregua
Summary: I have been working taking photography from some of the Mexican heritage dance groups since 2017 and I have a lot of images. I have worked mainly with two of these groups who takes seriously their task and they have high knowledges of their culture. I am also a published writer and editor. This project is to organize a photography and poetry book about this subject. I already have the photography and the poems will be presented in Spanish and English. The cover will have the image of one of the best known spiritual leader of this group in Houston.

Name: Preservation Houston
Summary: Preservation Houston is the only organization in Houston that presents guided walking tours focusing on the architectural and social history of the city's historic districts and neighborhoods. The docent-led tours are held the second Sunday of the month from January through November in different locations each month. The tour schedule changes every year. PH also presents quarterly guided tours of historic Glenwood Cemetery, held the fourth Saturday in February, May, September and November. Tours have a different theme each quarter, including Art & Architecture of Glenwood and the Women of Glenwood.

Name: Pride Chorus Houston
Summary:
Pride Chorus Houston is Houston's LGBTQ+ affirming choral group and annually produces a season of choral music concerts along with a slate of free community concerts for the Houston community. Our music inspires people with the beauty and resilience of the LGBTQ+ community in Houston. During the grant period, we plan to produce four ticketed concerts: one in April, June, October, and December. In
FY2024, we performed free concerts in connection with the Rice University Moody Center for the Arts, Houston AIDS Walk, and more. Through our programming, we reached over 2,100 ticketed patrons and many others through community events.

Name: Project Row Houses
Summary: Project Row Houses is a year-round community platform that fosters art and collective creative action fed by an ongoing dialogue with our Third Ward neighbors, artists from historically marginalized backgrounds, and the larger Houston community. Visitors enjoy an evolving series of free, temporary public art installations, as well as some permanent ones in and around our 5-block, 39-building site. That site includes the Eldorado Ballroom, a recently rehabilitated landmark building and venue for performing arts, as well as restored row houses,  the architectural vernacular of the neighborhood, used as studios, galleries, and programming space.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Raul Orlando Edwards
Summary: Evolucin!  a multidisciplinary theatrical presentation on the evolution of art-forms in the Americas  from North, Central, South and the Caribbean  and how society influenced them and how they influenced society. Evolucion vividly depicts the Indigenous, the European in a vibrant and colorful performance taking place on March 30, 2025 at MATCH Houston. Over 20 incredible and multi-talented artists, scholars and visual artists  locally and internationally known - participate in a production full of rich and lively aspects of the culture fueled by extensive historical research.

Name: ROCO
Summary:
ROCO is a classical music ensemble flexing from 1-40 professional musicians performing intimate concerts in dozens of venues in three concert series:
In Concert features ROCO's full 40-piece chamber orchestra performing new music, forgotten favorites, and well-known works from various eras.
Unchambered empowers individual musicians from the ensemble to curate their own concerts.
Connections are site-specific performances in collaboration with arts and cultural organizations and other unique venues throughout the Greater Houston region.

Name: Ronnie Self
Summary: I am a professor of architecture at the Hines College of Architecture and Design at the University of Houston. I will give an illustrated, public presentation of my current research and book project, The Architecture of Art Museums in Texas, at the College during the fall semester 2025 (between September and November 2025). The exact date is to be determined.

Name: See a Need - Meet a Need Foundation (SANMAN)
Summary: The See A Need - Meet A Need Foundation (SANMAN) strengthens Houstons creative ecosystem through art and cultural programming. Regardless of age, race, or socioeconomic background, we provide the space, tools, mentorship, and platform for artists and creative individuals to develop their craft. A core component of our organization is Sanman Studios, our 11,000-square-foot warehouse headquarters in Downtown Houston. Through quarterly exhibitions, our SANMAN Artist Residency, SANMAN Academy and our Creative Care Initiative, we activate year-round to meet the needs of emerging artists in the Greater Houston Area and uplift the BIPOC communities that support them.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Sara Gaston
Summary: I plan to do a work in progress screening via Zoom during May 2024.  Because so many festivals exclude films that have had a previous public presentation, this will allow me to share the work and not compromise festival inclusion.  I will include the cast & writer in a post-screening Q & A to answer any questions and raise awareness.  I also plan to have Houston screenings toward the end of 2025 through the Houston Film Commission (First Thursdays) and Houston Film Meet.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Sarah Sudhoff
Summary: Theater of War" will include the development of two socially-engaged works in response to the alarming increase in gun violence in the USA. "Fading Union," a performance documented through video, will include a figures repetitive actions as they wash, dye and bleach the same red American flag. "77 Minutes," a collaboration with the Uvalde families, will feature intimate photographs of the shoes their children were wearing during the Robb Elementary school shooting paired with portraits of the families. First Unitarian Universalist Church of Houston will host these new works during National Gun Violence Awareness Month in June.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Sara Van Buskirk
Summary: Join us for an unforgettable evening as we unveil the companion visuals for Sara Van Buskirk's self-titled album, a project partially funded by the City of Houston through the Houston Arts Alliance. This exclusive showcase will feature stunning visuals that complement Sara's music, creating a rich, immersive experience that highlights Houston's vibrant arts scene, raises the voices of the marginalized and celebrates queer love. Don't miss this unique event that promises to amplify the cultural impact of Sara's work and bring our community together in celebration of creativity and diversity. Hosted by Georgia Park Studios, October 3, 2025 @ 6:30pm.

Name: Segundo Barrio Children's Chorus
Summary: Houston's first-and-only bilingual children's chorus, Segundo Barrio Children's Chorus transforms the lives of children in Second Ward, Fifth Ward, Magnolia Park, and the greater East End District through tuition-free music instruction, and performance opportunities at community and city-wide events. Our performances highlight the importance of equal-access, representation, and bilingualism in the arts while also sharing with all Houstonians the rich cultural traditions and music of the latino/ hispanic/immigrant community. Programming includes after school classes & performing ensembles for children ages 4-13 as well as our annual Summer Music Camp and Community Concert, the largest arts event for hispanic children in Houston.

Name: Society for Indo-American Arts (SIA)
Summary: We have scheduled a Season of 10 in-person events in 2025 at MATCH, Wortham Center, and Stafford Centre, all being hubs of cultural arts activity in Houston including: March 30 - Zakir Hussain's Masters of Percussion, April 20 - Shahid Parvez Khan, Shakir Khan, May 9 - Rakesh Chaurasia-Shahank Subramaniam, June 20 - Indian Jazz Journey, Aug 30 - Sacred Winds. These events, covering disciplines of music, dance, and world music, are carefully selected keeping in mind the cross-cultural mission of the organization.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Slade Ham
Summary: The One That Got Away is a new stand-up comedy special. The material in this hour-long performance primarily focuses on the exit process from abusive relationships, and explores our human approach to survival, the wildness of nature, and the malleability of reality. In the style of past specials, the performance will be recorded live over two shows and edited into a feature film. Principal photography will occur September 2025 (Midtown Arts & Theater Center or equivalent) with a Dec 2025 release.

Name: Stages
Summary: Founded in 1978, Stages is Houstons sixth-largest nonprofit performing arts producer overall and the largest outside the downtown theater district. Stages is one of the regions leading artistic employers, producing an average of 10 productions annually totaling 350+ performances and welcoming tens of thousands of visitors each season. Our focus on producing a broad range of plays and musicals in an intimate setting has generated critical acclaim and created a devoted community of audiences and artists who share a true sense of engagement, inclusion, and connection.

Name: TEATRX
Summary: La Vida Es Cortos/Life Is Shorts is a unique festival that presents short plays and short films to highlight the Latinx community, its artists, and its stories. Short films and short plays are seldom seen by the general public but even more rare is seeing Latinx arts featured in Houstons prominent arts scene. In its seventh year, the festival will add childrens programming, a dance theatre performance, and dance short films to create a one-of-a-kind Latinx multidisciplinary, multigenerational experience. The festival will be presented at MATCH in October 2025.

Name: The Alta Arts
Summary: At The Alta Arts, we celebrate the limitless potential of artists of all ages, backgrounds, and lived experiences. Our goal is to provide a dynamic space where creativity knows no boundswhether through photography, theater, music, or mixed media. We host a diverse array of events, from student fairs and orchestras to art exhibitions that educate about American history. By fostering an environment where artists and the community combine different art forms, Alta Arts is dedicated to nurturing creative talent and ensuring accessibility for all to enjoy and experience.

Name: Community Artists' Collective Exhibition and Conversation
Summary: Community Artists Collective invites Houston to engage in our series of five vibrant exhibitions beginning in February through November 2025 at our new location at 4111 Fannin within The Ion Districts new retail development, Thursday through Saturday, 12pm - 5pm. Exhibitions explore unique perspectives at the intersections of African American history, art, and culture within the broader human experience. The Collective will also host The Witness Series, a four-part meditative public engagement in green spaces around Houston from February to May 2025.  All events and experiences are free, accessible, and open to the public off all ages.

Name: Ashley Hoskins
Summary: We Are The Ones Who Fly is an interactive performance set to happen in June 2025 in Houston's Third Ward. We Are The Ones Who Fly engages a diverse audience in the mystical world of African American oral storytelling. This is achieved by incorporating audience participation, musical instruments, and props to dramatize oral storytelling. In addition to performative storytelling, guests will engage in discourse about the myth of flying Africans and what it means to the preservation of African American folklore. Expect the space to be magically transformed to honor the ancestors who took flight back to Africa.

Name: The Garden Theatre
Summary: The Garden Theatre is committed to bringing meaningful art featuring semi-professional performers to our city. As one of Houstons most exciting new theatres, our goal is to tell relatable stories using unconventional casting to appeal to diverse audiences consisting of people from all different backgrounds and walks of life. Over the next year, our carefully chosen, audience-driven productions will include Doubt (March, 2025), While Childhood Slept (August, 2025, in partnership with Holocaust Museum Houston), Dracula: A Comedy of Terrors (October, 2025), and Little Women (December, 2024).

Name: John P. McGovern Museum of Health & Medical Science
Summary: As the nation's only interactive health museum, a proud member of the Association of Science and Technology Centers (ASTC), and the only Smithsonian Affiliate Museum in the Houston Museum District, The Health Museum is a culturally significant educational asset that attracts learners of all ages.  The Museum offers a unique perspective on the human experience through the lens of health, medical science, arts, technology and innovation.  The Museum's offerings include prominent traveling exhibitions from organizations like the Smithsonian and the American Museum of Natural History on topics such as artificial intelligence, dyslexia, and the human biome.

Name: The Hobby Center for the Performing Arts
Summary: The Hobby Center, one of Houstons leading and largest performing arts organizations, will serve 500,000 visitors during the 2024-25 Season with touring Broadway and other programming showcasing both local and global talent. The season includes nine Broadway productions, three Beyond Broadway concerts, nine Live at the Founders Club performances, ten ExxonMobil Discovery Series engagements, and six to ten other presentations. Our new mission transforms the organization, celebrating Houston artists and strengthening our performing arts ecosystem. Building on years of success presenting the best of Broadway, we reflect Houston's diversity through a wide range of expanded artistic and educational programming.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Thomas Helton
Summary: Recently a conflict between two of the rap/hip-hop community's top artists, Drake and Kendrick Lamar, played out online. I will compose an interpretation through contemporary opera and dance. This new piece will feature Houston's contemporary music ensemble, Relative Dissonance along with dance troupe Group Acorde and member of Houston Ebony Opera.

Name: Texas New Music Festival
Summary: Texas New Music Festival 2025 brings an international cohort of sixty composers, conductors, and instrumentalists to Houston for an eight-day celebration of new music. The entire festival will be housed at MATCH from July 6th to 13th, where TNMF will present seven concerts, an evening of film scores, 15 open rehearsals, and six guest lectures to the public. With a strong focus on Houston artists, our 2025 festival will feature a 15-piece sinfonietta comprised entirely of Houston-based performers and thirty-plus world premiere performances.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Vincent Victoria
Summary: The Prince/Rick James film project will be the first film ever to tackle the complicated relationship between the two revered musical geniuses who were also archrivals. The film will evenly balance the characterization of each musician by peeling back their show business facades and explore their stark personality differences as well as their tangible similarities. The filming would begin in late Winter 2025 and would make its World Premiere on Saturday June 7, 2025, at Midtown Art Center at 7pm.The date is also the anniversary of Prince's birth.

Name: Weston Twardowski
Summary: SPILL, Leigh Fondakowski's 2015 documentary theatre piece detailing the history of the Deepwater Horizon disaster, will take place at Rice's Moody Center for the Arts from April 09-11, 2025 (three performances, with evenings and matinees). The free production will invite Houston audiences into conversations about the impact of the disaster and the future of the city's role as the Energy Capital of the World. Leading experts on the Oil and Gas industry and Coastal Resilience will discuss the plays themes in a series of planned conversations. Local actors and designers will be hired to mount the production.

Name: What It's Like Project
Summary: REEL MENTAL | MENTALLY UNREAL: A one-night event showcasing a collection of mental health short films created by filmmakers around the world, capturing 'what its like' to experience mental health disparities. This event will be held virtual and in-person at Rec Room Theatre in Houston, TX on January 10th, 2025 from 6:30PM-9:00PM.

Name: WindSync
Summary: In 2025, WindSyncs 16th season continues with a concert at Rice University on February 13, the Onstage Offstage Chamber Music Festival from April 7-12, continued partnerships with HISD schools, the Center for Performing Arts Medicine, and public spaces in Houston, plus a concert in collaboration with Musiqa on November 1. The Onstage Offstage Chamber Music Festival will feature WindSyncs annual collaboration with the HYS Coda Music Program and a world premiere by composer Akshaya Avril Tucker. WindSync will also record an album celebrating the centenary of Nadia Boulangers Lectures on Modern Music delivered in Houston.

Name: Writespace
Summary: Writespace provides year-round evening/weekend programming in the Writespace studio at Sabine Street Studios and on Zoom. Programing also includes free events such as monthly readings & open mics on the last Friday of each month, monthly arts and literature events (Art in the A.M. and The Submissions Room), and our annual week-long events where writers can immerse themselves in the writing community, focus on their writing, and engage a community of readers with city wide literary events. Writespace provides scholarships to low income and marginalized writers in hopes of reaching these voices so they may examine their experiences through writing.

Name: Young Audiences of Houston
Summary: Young Audiences of Houston will provide free programs to the public in partnership with local organizations, cultural districts, social service agencies, parks, community centers, libraries, hospitals, businesses and other public venues open to the general public. These programs enable the community and visitors to Houston to participate in meaningful, high-quality arts experiences while promoting Houston as a national tourist destination with relevant, diverse arts and cultural experiences for all ages, backgrounds, and abilities. Over 61.7% of our annual 3,497 Arts & Culture Programs are open to the public and will take place from January 1, 2025 - December, 31, 2025 across Houston.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Christopher Stephen Young
Summary: All Souls Show" is a new original play written by Hunt Scarrit. Mr.Scarritt is a prodigy of Tony, Pulitzer award winning playwright Edward Albee ( Who's Afraid of Virginia Wolf, Sea Scape}. And Also a student of Tony, Pulitzer award winner August Wilson (Fences, Ma Rainey's Black Bottom)."All Souls Show" is a play based on the Catholic holiday All Souls Day . The play's setting is a cemetery at the De Roblachave crypt,  where the restless souls of the two characters Miss Adelle and Marcus John De Roblachove actions end in sance.10/31/2025 @7pm,November1st@7pm, 11/2/2025 @2pm,  3414 LaBranch (Midtown Arts Center).

Name: Loren Holmes
Summary: This performance explores the environmental impact of waste in our neighborhoods and the transformative power of collective action. Through movement and storytelling, dancers will depict the cycle of pollution and neglect, followed by the renewal and hope that emerge when communities unite to clean and restore their environment. Set against the backdrop of a dump site in 5th Ward, this piece serves as both a call to action and a celebration of the resilience of our neighborhoods and the earth. This project is set to take place May 3rd, 2025 at 6pm and November 8th, 2025 at 6pm.

Name: Loren Holmes
Summary: Creativity Connects is a dynamic event series empowering families and is designed to foster connections, share resources, and overcome challenges, all in a welcoming and understanding environment. These events provide valuable tools and networking opportunities, health and wellness sessions, and honest conversations that aim to see what it is the community truly needs to grow. The first session is scheduled for August 23, 2025 at 11am. It will be held at the Acres Homes Multi-service Center. Attendees will also have the opportunity to witness performances by local dance artists and musicians.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Gilberto Giles-Sosa
Summary: Untitled High School Drama Series will culminate in a screening of the proof of concept short and reading of completed pilot script with visuals, including concept art, storyboards, and lookbook. Proof of concept will be filmed with Texan actors and crew, and presentation of script will consist of a reading of pilot from start to finish, featuring cast members bringing their characters to life! Event will take place during Houston Theater Week (August 2025) at Midtown Arts and Theater Center Houston. Event will be free and open to the public, and of interest to educators, school administrators, and arts-related nonprofits.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Babatunde Ogunseinde
Summary: The Gathering" is an interactive, multidisciplinary event that immerses attendees in traditional and modern African art. Combining an art exhibit, musical concert, and social gathering, it brings the community together to celebrate and experience visual, performance, and musical art rooted in the African diaspora. The event offers a diverse range of presentations to attract a broad audience, providing a unique opportunity to celebrate and showcase Africa's cultural heritage while promoting unity and understanding among its people.

Name: Tarami Readus
Summary: Get ready to move, groove, and be inspired in Legacy, the evolution of Houstons African American culture. This production will feature a number of Houston musicians, and artists, and a host of community members that have been engaged in the project over the past year, where they have been learning traditional African rhythms and applying them to todays culture and society. This interactive musical showcase will be held on December 13th, 2025 and will be located at the historic Deluxe Theater, located on 3330 Lyons Avenue, Houston, TX 77020.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Farrah Fang
Summary: As a curator I will select emerging Texan trans and nonbinary artists of different mediums for an arts exhibition. My goal is to platform local BIPOC artists who otherwise wouldnt have the opportunity to participate in formal art spaces due to transphobia, racism, poverty and other detrimental factors. With the success of my previous event, sponsored by The Idea Fund, I plan to expand this into a recurring series of art shows for the trans community in Houston. With the growth of this project, I will be able to incorporate different artists, organizations, discussions, workshops, community resources and mentorship possibilities.

Name: Gulf Coast: A Journal of Literature and Fine Arts
Summary: The Gulf Coast Reading Series provides rich cultural programming focused on excellence and diversity in literature and the arts. One Friday a month, September through April, Gulf Coast Journal gathers audiences from Houston and afar at the Lawndale Arts Center to enjoy a night of reading from established and emerging readers. Readings are recorded and streamed online, reaching thousands of people nationally and internationally a year. Headline readers also provide free and public craft talks Saturdays following the readings. This year, the Artists Interface series will build off of the reading series platform to bring greater attention to visual artists.

Name: Katie Leigh Creeggan-Rios
Summary: This project centers around a short film which uses humor to address the many issues surrounding menopause. This production features local Houston talent in every area of production. We will be presenting the film at River Oaks Theatre in September of 2025  along with a panel of experts to talk about menopause and how it is portrayed in cinema. We will also be entering it in the local film competitions as well.  This set will also be used as a training set as part of a cooperative agreement with HCC.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Tremaine McIntire-Thomas
Summary: Join us on April 20, 2025, at the beautiful BH Ranch in the culturally rich community of Hiram Clarke for Abstract Visions, a live showcase of Houston's greatest artists across various disciplines. Enjoy 4/20 with live music, delicious food vendors, and captivating art, beats, lyrics, and poetry. We're confident you'll love it so much that we're doing it again on October 31st for Halloween!

Name: Philip Karjeker
Summary: An in-person presentation where I talk through the poetic, photographic, and drawing/painting explorations guided by open-ended questions around what a queer monument for Houston would be. This event will include a showing/site-specific installation of the work associated with this artistic research. Additionally, this presentation will be open to any community members I collaborated with to show our work together or give them the opportunity to present their own independent work. Taking place in the Winter of 2025 at Alabama Song or Basket Books and Art.

Name: Skyler Smith
Summary: WET:LAND is a multidisciplinary projectall at once a physical art installation, a designed landscape system, a lecture series, and a documentary short filmthat demystifies the important role of wetlands for climate adaptation and resilience in Greater Houston. Centered around the physical installation on display at POST HTXs Art Club Exhibition, the lecture series, which features four local wetland experts, will take place throughout March and April 2025; and the film, which involves the lecturers, will premiere in August 2025. At the core of WET:LAND sits the intention to co-create re-imagined understandings of the Houston-wetland relationship.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Sujaila Miranda
Summary: With HAAs support I will host a performative book presentation with a poetry open mic. Two actors will perform some of the poems from my poetry book, and one violinist will accompany them. The event will take place at Inprint, located next to The Menil. Entrance will be free. After the performance, there will be a brief Q&A session. Then we will have an integration moment with appetizers. Finally, we will close the event with a bilingual poetry open mic session. The event would take place on December 6th at 6pm-8:30pm.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: William Molina
Summary: Our public presentations would be held at prominent artistic venues in Houston including the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston (MFAH) and the Midtown Arts and Theater Center Houston (MATCH), and additional local venues that showcase local artistic works. The main screening event will take place early October, ideally. Additional screenings and interactive workshops will be hosted throughout October-Nov. These events will feature panel discussions with local artists and community leaders, followed by Q&A sessions and networking opportunities.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Antoine Culbreath
Summary: A live comedic courtroom drama! The Plaintiffs are wrestlers. The Defendants are wrestlers. Even the judge, Justis Law, but not the bailiff. The bailiff is the referee.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Seven Walker
Summary: Yslas Digitales: Empowering the Body as Data will take place at Insomnia Gallery on March 2025, starting at 6 PM. This audio-visual dance experience, developed by Seven Walker and featuring music by J.E. Hernndez, transforms participants' movements into dynamic data visualizations. The project aims to counteract the alienation caused by technology, empowering younger, lower-income, queer communities of color by rendering their presence as interactive digital art. By centralizing their movements and body language, Yslas Digitales fosters a transformative dialogue between individuals and technology.

Name: Adam Castaneda
Summary: The Four of Us is a new dance work created by an international team of artists, including Adam Castaneda (Houston, Texas), Ana Paula Ornelas (Hermosillo, Mexico), and Domokos Kovacs (Budapest, Hungary). This new work combines three distinct movement practices to form a single exploration of love, loss, and hope that will be presented at Dance Source Houston's Mind the Gap showcase on March 18, 2025. This collaboration sees three artists attempting to engage in a practice of caretaking and support for one another, all three bound together through their meeting at the international Art Omi residency in July 2023.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Adam Castaneda
Summary: Carnegie Summer is a series of pop-up dance performances celebrating the Carnegie Neighborhood Library & Center for Learning, and its contribution as a foundational institution within the Latinx neighborhood of Near Northside. Over a ten week period in summer 2025, Adam Castaneda will create dance inspired by the library's history and significant community members who have utilized the library throughout their personal journeys. Carnegie Summer will also include free Modern dance classes and activities in conjunction with the library's kids' reading program, as well as a presentation of an acclaimed children's dance theatre piece from Mexico City.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Erika Said Izaguirre
Summary: The public launch of my debut Spanglish-language novel, Burning Bridges, will celebrate and cement Houstons place as a haven and laboratory for Latina artists, and open new avenues for Spanglish literature as a genre.  The event will feature my book alongside women artists of the community from which it came and on which it is based.  In a space decorated by Houstons Latina artists, readings from my novel will alternate with poetry and music.  The event will take place in December 2025 at Inprint, a downtown Houston arts event space (exact date and time TBD six months in advance).

Name: Opera Leggera
Summary: Founded in 2005, Opera Leggera is the only professional musical theater based in the City of Houston presenting diverse programming to Northeast Houston communities. From vibrant musical-theatrical productions to compelling plays and concerts, Opera Leggera productions are curated by the theaters women-led creative team with the mission to present quality cultural performances to audiences of all ages and backgrounds. Opera Leggera requests funding for its 20th season which will include performances of 'Puttin' on the Ritz: 20 Years of Opera Leggera' (3/2025), a 3-day summer music festival (07/2025), 'It's The Holiday Season' (12/2025), and a mini concert series.

Name: The Re-Education Project
Summary: Building on the first iteration of Project 1444, a digital collection of essays that explored the history of European colonization and enslavement of Africa/African Diaspora before the year 1619, this iteration will develop a documentary film. 1619 marked the beginning of enslavement in Virginia but the actual beginning of European enslavement of African people began in 1444. This documentary seeks to reach a wider audience for the project through the arts and to dive deeper into the topic. The film will premiere on September 6th, 2025 at MATCH and will include a screening and a talkback with the cast members.

Name: Asian American Arts & Culture Initiative
Summary:
We have three exhibitions planned:
1) Partnering with United Chinese American, Asian Texans for Justice, Austin Chinese American Network to exhibit Roots Unveiled Project. This project unveils the Chinese American history in Texas and showcase their daily life through visual arts include two installations and several paintings.  Tentatively City of Houston City Hall, Feb 2025.
2) Valor of Chinese American partnering with Committee of 100 featuring 5 to 10 Asian American military personnel.  Tentatively City of Houston City Hall, Nov 2025.
3) AANHPI Heritage Month Celebration with local artists in Houston Central Library, Houston Central Library, May 2025.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Alexandra Lukina
Summary: Down the Hatch,' a 7-minute animated short exploring a mothers alcoholism and recovery through a child's perspective, debuts online in late May 2025. Available worldwide on Vimeo or MILLER DREAM STREAMS. Our aim is to ignite discussions about supporting those affected by addiction, rather than isolating them from society. This all-ages premiere event features two parts: the film itself, followed by exclusive behind-the-scenes footage. The latter showcases the art of hand-drawn animation, aiming to inspire Houston's burgeoning animation community.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Caio Alves Diniz
Summary: Halfway and Back..." seeks to commission and present four new compositions for String Trio. The works will draw inspiration from the vibrant cultural backgrounds of Japanese-American violinist Emily Richardson, Brazilian cellist Caio Diniz and American violist Nicholas Lindell. The project culminates in a free public concert (October/November 2025) welcoming individuals of all ages and cultural backgrounds. Through the artistic lenses of each composer, we look to reflect Houstons pluralism with a program that illuminates the creative potential of diverse heritages converging in one artistic expression. Composers Angela Ortiz, Tian Qin, Catarina Domenici and Gavin Sol Goodrich.

Name: Carlie Thompson
Summary: I aim to present my drawings in an intimate environment, such as Bisong or Doshi House. The gallery would begin 01/26/25 at 7p. The purpose of the presentation is to show works that represent the increase in self-compassion. As I continue to expand my portfolio, I become a lot less rigid with myself.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Claudia Cepeda
Summary: The Community Built PlaySpace is a public art installation created collaboratively by high school students and community residents. Partnering with local STEM programs across Houston, students will design and construct modular pieces that foster resilience, enhance learning, and support social, emotional, and creative development. Following their construction, a series of pop-up events will invite local organizations, residents, and community leaders to paint the modular pieces, which will then be assembled into a unique Interwoven PlaySpace built by the community itself to promote resilience and healthy living.

Name: Deeper Than Dance
Summary: Our public presentation will take place in the fall of 2025 at the Midtown Arts and Theater Center Houston. It will be a 60-75 minute dance show that will intricately expand and conclude the story touched upon in our dance film titled "Ambition.

Name: DG Fine Arts
Summary: College & Culture Fest is a vibrant one-day festival taking place on MLK weekend at HCC-Central campus, showcasing the talents of student performing artists. Featuring performances by the Space City All-Star Band, PVAMU Marching Storm, and TSU Ocean of Soul, the festival highlights Houston's cultural heritage. It offers engaging activities like food trucks, games, and music, creating an inclusive atmosphere. Core components include workshops for students on finance, artistic development, technology, and entrepreneurship, providing valuable skills. The festival aims to celebrate diversity, educate and advocate for the arts, and inspire the community, ultimately becoming a staple of Houston's cultural calendar.

Name: Small Places
Summary: The Salsa de Mayo Festival is an annual celebration in Houston's East End community, centered around the start of the fresh tomato season. This family-friendly event highlights the local agricultural heritage, particularly focusing on the Finca Tres Robles urban farm, and brings together the community through food, music, and cultural activities. The 2025 festival is scheduled for May 17th, from 10 AM to 3 PM, at the Finca Tres Robles urban farm located at 5715 Canal St., Houston, TX.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Amanda Shih
Summary: Grown-up Storytime (GUST) is a crowdsourced storytelling event that happens every third Tuesday at 8pm at Houstons Continental Club. GUST collects personal stories to be read by performers in front of a live audience, creating funny, heartwarming, and exciting storytelling magic. We invite artists and audiences to collectively share experiences in an accessible environment, building community and inspiring further participation. GUST prioritizes diversity and sincerity in storytelling: achieved by open calls for submissions, providing constructive feedback and resources for artists, and recruiting performers at all experience levels, backgrounds and identities to perform.

Name: Holy Family HTX Episcopal Church
Summary: To make our gallery more accessible, we hired a part-time gallery docent who welcomes guests with extended hours ensuring that all visitors receive a warm welcome and can learn more about the art and artists in our gallery. Our involvement in local events and collaborations with cultural organizations ensures our project remains inviting and accessible to both the community and the broader public. Fridays and Saturdays from 11 AM to 6 PM. Additionally, we offer visiting hours on Sundays from 9 AM to 12 PM.

Name: Loop38
Summary: Loop38 is a musician-led new music ensemble whose mission is to bring Houstonians together around innovative, stimulating, and culturally relevant musical experiences. In 2025, Loop38 will continue creating unique artistic experiences for the city by performing in traditional and non-traditional venues, collaborating with composers and artists of various disciplines, continuing its educational and outreach programs, and bringing new music to Houston.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Lotus Bermudez
Summary: Ni Howdy: Ceramic Sculpture Exhibition is a celebration of the vibrancy of Houston's multicultural perspective from the voice of a local Tex-Asian artist. The sculptural works will be on public display towards the end of 2025 and stimulate dialogue and thoughts about geographical and cultural identity as well as resilience while highlighting the ceramic arts in Houston.

Name: The Menil Collection
Summary: The Menil Collection requests an HAA Support for Organizations grant to support its operations in 2025. The Menil plans a variety of programs to attract, engage, and inspire visitors from Greater Houston and beyond, including special exhibitions, artist lectures, symposia, performances, and film screenings. Set in a residential neighborhood in the Montrose district, the Menil fosters meaningful encounters with art, and welcomes all visitors free of charge, always.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Brian Ellison
Summary: This Is Not a Performance," is an exploration of housing injustice and the relentless chase for the American dream, uniquely conveyed through performance art. Using a treadmill as a symbolic vehicle, I will perform in various liminal spaces such as barbershops, laundromats, and gentrifying neighborhoods. These pop-up events will occur throughout the city, culminating in a final exhibition at the Deluxe Center in Fifth Ward. Experience the physical and emotional toll of overwork and systemic exploitation.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Travis Prokop
Summary: Coded: Conversations You Didnt Know We Were Having" is an immersive evening of dance, theatre, and drag performance expected for June 2025. Produced by Travis Prokop, an Assistant Professor of Dance at the University of Houston, this project delves into how LGBTQ+ people communicate in personal and societal relationships. The project will be performed in an unconventional venue like Sanman Studios or Heights Ironworks. This project increases awareness of LGBTQ+ topics in concert dance while creating accessible work that anyone can identify with under the commonality of relating to what it feels like to be misunderstood.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Vanessa Provencio
Summary: After completing our short film, "Wings," screenwriter Sameer Ketkar and I are going to rent out a theater in downtown Houston for the public screening in October or November 2025. We are considering the IPIC theater in the Galleria area, as well as private venues like the BLACK BOX theater rehearsal space in the Second Ward. We will promote the public screening through social media and word of mouth, with the hope of attracting as much buzz as we can.

Name: Social Movement Contemporary Dance Theater
Summary: SMCDTs first performance of 2025 will be February 21 & 22 at 7:30pm for Artists for Hope, a benefit concert that raises funds for charitable organizations in Houston. We will then travel to Kalamazoo, Michigan, to present at the Midwest Regional Alternative Dance Festival (RAD) on Saturday, March 2. Following the RAD, we will present "The Best of Both Worlds" featuring two world premieres. We will celebrate International Dance Day with "Dance in the Bayou City", at Discovery Green on Sunday, April 27 from 11:00am  7:00pm. Fall programming includes the Hunger Action Month Dance Festival in September.

Name: Virtual Arts for Humanity (VAH)
Summary: From 4-7pm on September 6, 2025, Virtual Arts for Humanity (VAH) will stage our performing arts festival followed by a post-performance attendee panel (9/5-9/7 marks all festival-related plans). This years elemental theme will be water, providing artists the creative freedom to collaborate. Our programming will uplift and inspire emerging performers, aspiring arts educators, and foster unity to celebrate Houstons diverse community. Performers from across Houston, audience members, and local leaders will come together at MATCH, located in the heart of Houston, to celebrate the artistry and creativity that brings hope to humanity.

Name: Vitacca Ballet
Summary: Creation House' is a new project produced by Vitacca Ballet this season. This piece allows our company artists to dig deeper into the creative process, both as choreographers and performers. The performance will be presented in an intimate box theatre as if the company is inviting the audience into their living room, where we are one artistic family unfolding the work together. Nine different pieces will be created by the artists both developing their dialogue and giving them the opportunity to share their individual voices, expanding the overall artistic awareness of the City of Houston.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Elizabeth Sosa Bailey
Summary: The public presentation HOOPZTOWN, an originally Houston, television pilot script includes an open-to-the-public staged reading with full cast, strategically inviting sports aficionados, educators, and film supporters. With Houston casting calls deploying December 2024, auditions finalized January 2025, and production design and mood boards developed February, the reading will take place in March 2025 on a weeknight at UHs Quintero Theatre before filming begins in May. A secondary event welcoming key stakeholders and members of Houstons film, television, and cultural arts community is slated for September 2025 at Eldorado Ballroom to publicly present the first cut of the filmed episode.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: John Nicklos II
Summary: Coloring for the Culture is an immersive dive in the the rich histories of Houston's Historic Black Neighborhoods through community style lifesize "paint by number" coloring. Residents from around the city have partnered with local artists to transform a local art studio into a giant comicbook that tell the stories of their unique neighborhoods and communities. Pull up and meet your neighbors (literally) while making friends as you explore Houston's Black history through the art of community coloring. June 15-21, 2025 from 11am-6pm daily at Project Row Houses. Closing Ceremony and comicbook unveiling, June 22, 2025 at 1pm.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Julie Bata
Summary: Sahel Suite: Playing with Time" is a West African solo dance performance to be shared with the Houston community through performance and community engagement. Drawing on traditional forms of dance and music from West Africa, I will create a suite of three dances in collaboration with musician Gabriel Bata.  I plan to perform the suite in the round at Mers Stage on Houston Community College Central Campus, followed by audience participation and a Q&A. In addition, I will apply to Dance Source Houstons Mind the Gap and Barnstorm Dance Festival for additional performance opportunities of the dances as singular pieces.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Melissa Graham
Summary:
My art installation of rape whistles will shed light on the many victims of sexual violence in America.
Born from personal experiences with trauma, my current work is driven by my fascination between the interwoven relationships of the body, mind and spirit. Im a survivor. A secret Ive kept through the shadows of anxiety, depression, and a C-PTSD diagnosis. This is my life; the lens I work within and around.
This installation will cause the viewer to pause, engage and reflect. I am a proud Houstonian and Houston can handle hard things. Houston Strong.
Virtual event- February 4, 2025, 12pm.

Name: Tian Qin
Summary: The public presentation of the project "imUnsure" will take place in Spring 2025 (a day in April or May) at 7:30 pm at Asia Society Houston or Wortham Theater at the Shepherd School of Music at Rice. The presentation will be in the form of a piano solo recital with multimedia components, such as live electronics, and projector, etc.

Name: Rachel Dickson
Summary: American Myths is a project to be executed September 27 and October 4, 2025, intending to challenge Houstonians and visitors to explore an inescapable presentation highlighting Houstons history and contribution to the propagation of myths in the teaching of American history. Multiple brief presentations of various disciplines will be presented to the public at no charge in public spaces such as Allens Landing on Buffalo Bayou and Emancipation Park which are spaces that have a defined and undeniable relationship to the realigned history.

Name: Toba Atkins-Montana
Summary: A-Simulation is a Modern, and soft acrobatic interactive dance piece that broadly dissects the systematic practices of Assimilation V. Acculturation and its effects on BIPOC communities. A-Simulation will be presented live and virtually from January 10, 2025 at 7:30 PM through Jan.11, 2025 with two showings, a 2:30 Matinee and 7:30 PM Closing, at The Interchange located at 1815 Cleburne, Houston TX. The film will continue playing on Social Media platforms (YouTube, Patreon, and Instagram) until March 30, 2025.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Flash Gordon Parks
Summary: May 2025 at the historic Eldorado Ballroom for a captivating exhibition that celebrates the rich musical heritage of the Lone Star State. Our preservation incubator will showcase a unique collection of music indigenous to Texas, meticulously gathered and preserved to pay homage to the states significant contributions to the global music community. We aim to introduce audiences to the diverse and influential sounds of Texas, fostering a deeper appreciation for its cultural legacy. The exhibition will be open to the public, offering a rare opportunity to experience the vibrant history of Texas through its most authentic medium  vinyl records.

Name: Tackle Your Dreams (TYD) Foundation
Summary:
This full day immersive experience at the Montrose Center includes workshops and panels that give attendees the courage and confidence in their art form to cultivate their talents into paid artistry/performances. The community at large gets a "backstage pass" into the world of performance art, with their opportunity to get on stage and practice what they learn. 
The theme is "Drag Saved My Life" which is centered in manifesting wealth, not only financially, but in knowledge, resources, mental health, and community support. Leading these conversations we are curating various experts including therapists, pageant experts, show directors, and seasoned  drag legends.

Name: Classical Arts Society of Houston (CAS)
Summary: In April 2025 we will be featuring the top of their tier Carnatic vocal duo Ranjani and Gayatri at MATCH - an example of our programming and how annually we feature world renowned top-tier musicians in Houston making it a top destination for Carnatic music in North America. We attract patrons and connoisseurs from  Greater Texas and North American region to Houston. We bring the best in class to Houston to inspire, promote and sustain arts & culture focused on next generation, as well to cater to current and senior citizens of the South Indian community and any one interested in arts

Name: Partnerschools
Summary: In October 2025, Partnerschools will offer a free public bucket drumming performance where participants can create their own drums, learn to drum and dance to the rhythm, and make joyful noise with new friends in the breezeway of The Hobby Center. Partnerschools will provide materials and instruction in the fundamentals of percussion, choreography, and a take-home craft: a drumstick! The program will culminate in an interactive, improvisational performance that is open to all.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Anthony Ogbo
Summary: This is a cartoon art exhibition titled, "My Humorous Brushstrokes." It is scheduled for April 7-11, 2025, during the 43rd Annual Media and Communication Conference (CommWeek) at the Texas Southern University at 3100 Cleburne St, Houston, TX 77004.
