CommWeek is a platform for community members, scholars, students, professionals, and civic leaders to discuss topics with cultural, political, economic, and social significance. The exhibition will showcase 20 cartoons that use humor and illustrations to reflect Houston's art and culture, showcasing the artist's creativity and expression from various perspectives.

Name: George Villanueva
Summary: MyAsianAmericanMarket will creatively explore Asian American diasporic foodways through participatory mapping community engagements at ethnic markets servicing the six largest Asian American populations in Houston (VietnameseViet Hoa International Foods, ChineseGreat Wall Supermarket, IndianKeemat, FilipinoFilTex, KoreanHmart, JapaneseSeiwa). These engagements will take place over six different Saturdays and Sundays in May, which aligns with AAPI heritage month. The maps collected from these engagements will be archived to show on a public website. A collective #MyAsianAmericanMarket print and digital map will also be designed in seven different languages and launched October 18th at a community event at the United Way of Greater Houston.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Gregory Cutaia
Summary: A child torn between divorcing parents flees to the woods.  A strange voice from a drainage pipe leads him to a hatch with an open door and a creaky edgeECHO is a surrealistic folk horror short focusing on sustainable multimedia integration and Latino representation. The public exhibition will showcase a test screening of the film as well as other Latino artists from Houston. Principal photography for the film will take place around Houston in November 2024 and the screening event will take place in 2025 most likely at MECA in the East End.

Name: Jakari Sherman
Summary: At a notable moment in Houstons history, "Our Road Home: Exploring Freedom as a Way of Life" is a three-part project taking place in Freedmens Town, Houstons First free black community, to commemorate its establishment and the 160th anniversary of emancipation. The project, taking place from May to July 2025 includes a public discussion, the premiere of a new site-specific multidisciplinary dance work, and a dance workshop series.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Jamal Cyrus
Summary: A multifaceted installation inspired by travel to the North African cities of Tangier, Fez and Casablanca will be presented at the African American History Research Center at the Gregory School. Composed of a series of diagrammatic scores and performances interpreting the scores, these works are part of a methodology I have been developing in collaboration with artist Leslie Hewitt, they echo the interconnected musical forms of Gnawa, the Blues, and Experimental Jazz. Tentative dates for the exhibition are August 2025 through October 2025.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: John Calderon
Summary: We will explore the fusion between several genres, drawing from the rich cultural environment of Houston. The 2025 SACI grant would enable us to take this sound into newer spaces, creating a sound that is uniquely Houstonian as well a live performance that will benefit the community and its visitors. We will (1) create new compositions/arrangements by Houston composers and musicians Mr. John Calderon and Dr. Jose-Miguel Yamal; (2) record these new works in a professional Houston recording studio; and (3) present the new works in a live performance in a public space open to Houstonians and visitors in 2025.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Katy Montoya
Summary: My public presentation will be a screening of an advanced version of my film that I spend 2025 making significant progress on. By then, all material will be shot, and I will present a 90-120 minute edited cut of the film. It will be screened at the microcinema 14 Pews (800 Aurora St, Houston, TX 77009) on Friday, November 21st at 8 PM. There will be a presentation of my work with Understanding Houston and the Kinder Institute for Urban Research followed by a Q&A and discussion with the audience.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Ren Beregan
Summary: In partnership with Actors Across Borders, I am hosting a screening and networking event for creatives to watch a live screening of "The Interview," meet each other, and form collaborations. The expected date will be in September 2025 at Axelrad (all ages are admitted before 8pm). Audiences will have further opportunities to watch "The Interview" when we screen it at Cafe Brasil (expected date of August 7, 2025) and, pending acceptance, at the Borders No Borders program at the Houston Cinema Arts Society film festival (November 2025).

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Ricardo Prez Dvila
Summary: this public presentation will take the form of a film screening. the exact location is still TBD, however, it will take place outdoors so that the public can have the experience of breathing in their local atmosphere while witnessing a story about air inequality. the screening will take place in the fall of 2025 (to avoid excessive heat) and last between one and two hours, with time for mingling, hydrating, light snacking, and a panel discussion with experts in atmospheric sciences and local air justice efforts. post-screening, the film will be distributed online and submitted to film festivals.

Name: Steven Saltsman
Summary: I'd like to bring "There Was and There Was Not" -- an original one-woman play about Armenian and Armenian-American culture -- to Houston. I'm in conversation to present this powerful and funny work at the newly renovated River Oaks Theatre January 10th-12th of next year, in time for the 110th anniversary of the start of the Armenian genocide. This play takes the form of an extended conversation with the audience about the history and culture of the Armenian people.

Name: Oni Chambers
Summary: Our public presentation for "Today I Cried" includes hosting both a table read of the script, as well as a community premier of the short film. The evening would include performances by additional community artists, featuring music and spoken word that echoes the topics of the film. We invite local artists, university students, and members of the Houston community to engage in a cathartic exhale as we explore common themes of love, loss, strife, and social and emotional despair. This free event would occur at Texas Southern University Communications Building, The MLK Production Studio on December 3rd, 2025.

Name: Jerrian Herd
Summary: HOU Know: A Legendary Tribute, is an intimate musical celebration of Houstons iconic artists, showcasing their global influence on music and culture. In a "Tiny Desk"-style live taping, several performers will bring legendary Houston tracks to life, highlighting the citys unique sound. This event will connect local communities and online audiences. Attendees will experience the live production on 5/3/25 at 3PM, at CCN Network production studios, while viewers worldwide can stream and celebrate Houstons musical legacy on 7/13/25... 713 day! This innovative tribute will cement Houstons cultural influence, blending live performance with digital reach for lasting impact.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Norma Jo Thomas
Summary: Writer, producer, director, Norma J. Thomas, returns to the Zilkha Theatre stage, June 14th, 2025, 7:30pm, ONE NIGHT ONLY, for the world premiere of "H Place", a play with music. "H Place" centers around the Harmony family,  pillars of the community. What should be their brightest moment is dimmed by family matters that threaten to ignite and send the entire Harmony legacy up in smoke.  Receiving highest scores across all Readers and awarded a Staged Reading at the Texas Educational Theatre Association 2022 PlayFest, "H Place" premiere comes at no better time than that of Houston's First Black Arts Festival.

Program: Support for Artists and Creative Individuals
Name: Lisa Lapinski
Summary: I propose to mount an exhibition of my own sculpture and photographs in a sublet space in the Museum District. The show will take place  October 4 - November 2, 2025  and be open to the public every weekend.  There will also be talks by local artists open to the public every Saturday during the run of the show.
